text:
Disclaimer: I am a lover of all things sweet and baked. I have been baking from scratch since I was in elementary school, from cookies to cream puffs to meringues and sponge cakes, and recently finished my baking quest for "perfect macarons," complete with feet! I've probably read almost all of the authoritative articles on macarons that the internet has to offer. That being said...

I know most people love this place. But, I am not a fan. I've tried these twice on separate occasions (other people kindly shared with me) and not been very impressed. When a place is very hyped up, I have very high expectations in mind.

The macaron shells were rather brittle and fragile, and at least for the ones I tasted (Boston Cream Pie and also a Salted Caramel, I believe), they crumbled pretty instantly upon taking a small bite. I was looking forward to a shell with more bite- slightly chewy along with semi-crackly/crumbly. The buttercreams that they were filled in were not memorable to me, and I wonder if it was the same buttercream with just different flavored shells? Was it buttercream? Whipped cream? Vanilla? I remember double checking with my friend, wait, what flavor are these again? The names are creative, but I didn't find the tastes as assertive as I would have expected. (My theory is that the word 'salted caramel' is a buzz word, and sounds so cool that anything called salted caramel will be tasty!)  

Another gripe I have is with the pudding. To me, I like a pudding to taste slightly custardy and very creamy and smooth. The black sesame pudding I tried had quite a few whole sesame seeds in it, and if I had been to make it, I would have increased the ratio of ground sesame to sesame seeds to accentuate the black sesame nutty taste. Texturally, I would not describe it as a pudding, but more of a milky jello, because it was definitely on the stiffer side. 

Sorry! I wanted to like you, Audabon.
name: Audabon Bakeshop
categories: Desserts, Bakeries, Food, Caterers, Event Planning & Services

text:
Yum, yum, YUM! Each tasty bite of Audabon Bakeshop's macarons has made me a happy little lady. I attempted to buy macs the day before, but they were sold out after 2.5 hours! I think that can attest to how great Audrey's little creations really are. 

It's not the first time I've had French macarons, but I was really impressed by the unique flavor profiles that Audabon had. I was lucky enough to go early today and picked up a variety of their Lunar New Year flavors among others. I bought: lotus pear, coconut lychee, pineapple rum cake, black sesame mochi, and mung bean lemon. 

It was my first time trying macarons with Swiss meringue buttercream and wow they're amazing. Not too sweet and the fruit compote in the middle of  some of the macarons was a nice surprise that lent a great combo of flavors and textures.

You have to buy the macarons in pairs (c'mon they're only $1.50 each), but they are lovely. I did not try the puddin' but after reading the reviews, I might have to try their salted caramel one! 

The only thing I didn't like about this place is that it's so addicting. Now I have to come back regularly!
name: Audabon Bakeshop
categories: Desserts, Bakeries, Food, Caterers, Event Planning & Services

text:
I've bought about 20 macarons from here by now. The flavors are always creative and the macarons always fresh and look carefully made. The people behind the counter are also friendly. At $1.50 a piece, this is actually a pretty good deal (for macarons). Macarons are expensive cookies for their size anyway, but from personal experience, they're not easy to make. I like the little jammy surprises in the center of each cookie. 

I also had the black sesame custard last time and it was good (if you like black sesame). But I shouldn't have eaten the whole thing in a few hours because all the sugar made me nauseous. Do share!
name: Audabon Bakeshop
categories: Desserts, Bakeries, Food, Caterers, Event Planning & Services

text: A year and a half later after visiting your stand at the suburban station....BOOM...a storefront.  Congrats Audrey and team!  I knew your heavenly and delicious creations would someday be sold at a cool store.  I could not wait to visit the shop.  Sadly there was only tomorrow's batch left.  I was told to actually wait to munch on them tomorrow since they would taste better.  I couldn't remember the thee flavors i had except for the mango jasmine.  I  also indulged in the black sesame pudding.  Weirdly delicious but i prefer the salted caramel.  I can't wait to get my hands on more!
name: Audabon Bakeshop
categories: Desserts, Bakeries, Food, Caterers, Event Planning & Services

text:
I pass by this shop quite often and never took the opportunity to walk in until today. Being the end of the day, most of her flavors were out (especially the ones I really wanted to try). However, the cashier (I assume Audrey the shop owner) was so outgoing and nice, I couldn't help but buy a few products.

I'm not a fan of sweets, but I have to say that the Black Sesame pudding was quite good! It was creamy and not quite sweet with a nice subtle black sesame taste. This place is definitely an Asian inspired bakery I would recommend!

I'm from New York, so I think I am quite fluent in the art of baked goods, so I have to say this place was quite good for the price. Never have I ever bought macarons at this price at this quality. Definitely a must try! 

Audrey, I hope this place becomes as famous as Laduree (overpriced, in my opinion).

Really recommend playing with some rose-water flavors. Makes a great new flavor profile.
name: Audabon Bakeshop
categories: Desserts, Bakeries, Food, Caterers, Event Planning & Services

text:
Yes - the texture & temperature of the froyo is inconsistent.  Yes - Yogorino is much creamier.

BUT - Sweet Ending has tons of toppings (added cereals & syrups), friendly service & new flavors.  

AND - on my last trip they had **BLACK SESAME** frozen yogurt.  I mixed that in with some green tea & topped with mochi & mango.  The cup in the picture cost $3.50.  AMAZING... the black sesame is less tart, more earthy and reminds me of Japan.

My bf mixed up a messy concoction of strawberry, vanilla, green tea yogurt with strawberries, mangoes, mochi, sprinkles & raspberries - he called it the beauty of diy yogurt.  His overflowing disaster in a cup ran $5.50.

For location, price & the joy of experimentation, we'll definitely be back.

They also added frequent buyer cards - 11th yogurt is free.
name: Sweet Cafe
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Food

text: First of all, I dig Froyo shops. I do, I cant help it. Most of them at least. This one however is exceptional. The flavors are unique and interesting. Black sesame vanilla? Darn good. I think the toppings at most shops are the same (but for the love of god, please stop offering crushed granola bars as an option...just weird). The price is lower than most other stores, and its clean and friendly. I really liked this place. Nicely done Yogurtland.
name: Yogurtland
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food

text: The best macaroons in philly with the best flavors. I love the sweet potato marshmallow which just reminds me of Thanksgiving and the coconut Thai tea which is quite possibly a combination of two of my favorite bubble tea flavors. The macaroons themselves are very well crafted with a light, crispy shell and creamy filling. They also have the capability to substitute other nuts like cashews and hazelnuts or seeds for a nut-free version, which is great!  I also love the black sesame pudding: sweet, creamy, and oh so aromatic. Of course the buttermilk panna cotta is still to die for. I am actually really really glad that I now live a good 12 blocks away because if I lived closer I would be horsing myself every single day. Unless they are closed of course.
name: Audabon Bakeshop
categories: Desserts, Bakeries, Food, Caterers, Event Planning & Services

text:
Came in on a Saturday early evening during their soft opening and was welcomed by staff. It was our first time here and there were a lot of dessert options to pick from. They have waffle combos which have their dipped cone on top of a waffle garnished with variety of toppings. They also have their original dipped cones that you can pick from: Matcha, strawberry, black sesame, chocolate etc. As well as some drinks. They do serve brunch until 4pm, and after that it seems it's strictly the dessert menu.
We opted to try the Catcha Matcha waffle combo, and two Frappes - Praline and Matcha. You can substitute the milk in the frappes for soy milk or coconut milk for an extra charge. 
We were surprised when the waffle combo came out as they also gave us two dipped cones! I'm not sure if that was just a promo during their soft opening but it was a nice surprise :)
Service was excellent and the food was great. Lactose Intolerant people be warned! There'll be a lot of dairy and the waffle combo is already quite filling for two people. 

The cafe itself is really pretty - Instagram worthy cafe for sure!
Would definitely recommend trying the desserts here if you have quite a sweet tooth. Can't wait to try out their brunch menu next time.

P. S Everyone has different tastes, no need to be so passive aggressive towards other reviewers if you didn't enjoy your meal. If it wasn't tasty to you, then it wasn't.
name: Cacao 70 Sweet House

text: 3.5 stars. It's a cute place. A good location since there aren't many good bakeries in Chinatown, so it's nice to come here after grabbing dinner. A good/unique variety of flavors for the macarons and pudding. Main issue was packaging as I ordered 6 macarons that were placed in a little plastic bag. By the time I took them home to let my kids try, they crumbled/broke, so it wasn't as cute eating them. I got the black sesame pudding which wasn't too sweet- never had anything like it. I really liked the pudding a lot and want to try the other flavors other reviewers recommended. One HUGE perk to this place is it's safe for my peanut allergy kid! Tree nuts are used but not peanuts, so yay!
name: Audabon Bakeshop
categories: Desserts, Bakeries, Food, Caterers, Event Planning & Services

text: This place is cozy but due to the prices only come here a few times with your rich friends so you can chat about who has the most diamonds on their engagement ring. We got the blackjack and catcha matcha waffles with salted caramel and mint chocolate frappés. The salted caramel didn't really taste like salted caramel but more like a normal frozen hot chocolate. The mint frappés mint flavor was pretty overwhelming and bitter it kinda tastes like medicine but idk I'm not fond of mint so that's probably just my opinion lol. This place is one of those cafes that look really good and the idea is amazing but the food is mediocre. Like it's kinda like an amusement park of food. The waffles are fairly sweet and I found it cute that they have cheesecake in top. These are pretty filling too. For the blackjack, the black sesame makes the waffles less sweet which I prefer and the mat ha was the one that was very sweet. Ok I hope I someone helped with my review!!!! The end
name: Cacao 70 Sweet House

text:
Best fresh fruit smoothies in Chinatown for the lowest price, none of that powder stuff! 

Favorites:
- Ham and egg bread $0.80
- Rice roll $2.00 (can ask for beef and shrimp too! And their sweet soy sauce for it is the BEST, ask for extra if you get take out!) 
- Stir fried noodles $1.50 (runs out fast, don't forget to add Sriracha if you like spicy :))

Interesting Teas I've grown to love:
- Black Sesame Tea (use fresh ground up black sesame seeds) 
- Lavender Tea (never thought I'd like this, but their lavender is so aromatic and calming)
- MANGO SMOOTHIE :)
name: Greenland Tea House
categories: Food, Tea Rooms, Coffee & Tea, Bakeries

text: My friend and I stopped by to share an order of the sweet black sesame soup with milk tea for dessert, and it was delicious! Spotted with the occasional whole sesame seed, it truly was as good as it gets!
name: Heung Fa Chun Sweet House

text:
It's been several years since my last review & my previous comments no longer apply; the price is about the only thing that hasn't changed.

The yogurt is often icy, there isn't much flavor turnover, and the less than fresh fruit toppings often look slimy.  I've been back frequently and not once have I seen the elusive black sesame yogurt.

The novelty has worn off.
name: Sweet Cafe
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Food

text:
While I do not frequent this establishment very often, when I do, it is a pure delight.  My parents are here almost once a week so I live vicariously through them in between visits.  I remember when I was in high school it was a greasy spoon diner known as Charcoal, Steak and Things.  Now it is the gem of Yardley borough serving classy food in creative ways.  

My review will be based upon the Kitchen Tasting I enjoyed this past December 2011, but I think it will give any reader some insight on the abilities and creativity of the chefs here.  I have posted pictures to accompany this review.  

First Course: Oyster: cherry, leek.  Before this tasting I had never had an oyster before.  I know, I know, it took me this long, but what a way to experience my first one!  We were presented with an oyster bathing in it's own juices, covered in thinly sliced leek and a cherry foam on top.  Unfortunately my experience was dominated by the flavor of the leek, but there was a subtle presence of the cherry foam and the oyster just melted away.  Impressive presentation.

Second Course: Scallop: lentil, grapefruit, frisee.  The scallop was cooked perfectly and paired well with the lentil.  I've never had lentil outside of soup so it was nice to experience it's true taste on it's own.  Paired with the scallop and frisee, there were many layers of textures ranging from soft and mushy to crisp crunch.  I should have asked the chef at the time, but I was left wondering what the purpose of the grapefruit was.  Possibly to cleanse the pallet after eating the scallop?

Third Course: Woodcock: polenta, cherry, sprout leaves.  Yes, I looked up a picture of a Woodcock right after I ate this course!  It looked like a cross between a woodpecker and a pigeon.  Found year round in the southeast, breeding in the northeast, this particular bird was from New York.  It's flavor was gamey, the breast not as gamey as the thigh.  Along with the creamy polenta and the bittersweet dried cherry, this was a unique course.  I preferred the flavor of the breast to the thigh greatly.  

Fourth Course: Trio of Duck.  I'm sorry to those that disapprove, but duck is GOOD!  We were presented with a thick cut of duck breast with a tasty layer of fat on top, a full duck heart and deep fried duck tongue.  I was surprised that the heart was pretty tender and almost tasted like a cut of filet mignon.  The tongue were like crispy little fried clams.  It was exotic without tasting as such.  I was really impressed with how it was presented as well.  

Fifth Course: Hanger Steak: turnip, red wine, broccoli rabe.  Hanger Steak, a.k.a. Butcher's Steak presents itself almost like a flank steak in it's look and texture but offers great flavor.  We were given a generous portion of steak atop turnip puree and red wine reduction.  Topped with broccoli rabe and pepper flakes, this was the course more familiar to my taste buds and eyes.  After the adventure of the first four courses, this was a treat to finish the savory dishes.

Sixth Course: Pliable Chocolate: black sesame, meringue.  First off, look at the picture I posted and how they presented this dish.  It was awesome!  I was never a big fan of sesame but when paired with chocolate, it really redefined the flavor for me.  There was this sesame 'dust' that just disappeared in your mouth, creamy toasted meringue, black sesame ice cream and chocolate ganache.  

If you can attend a tasting here, I highly recommend it as it really exposes you to things you may never order on your own.  You don't know what your going to eat until you arrive so there is a lot of excitement involved.  The chef presents each dish with a little explanation and will answer any questions you have.  The staff here is really friendly and the view overlooking the Delaware River just adds to the already pleasant ambiance.  Awesome job done by this place!
name: Charcoal

text:
Amazing macaroons. Amazing decor. Amazing service. Flavors are awesome and unique, and each macaroon is small enough for the perfect amount of satisfaction.

I absolutely enjoyed the apple pie macaroon (the apple sauce homemade in the center is just ridiculously good), but thought the black sesame pudding. I'm also a bit biased because I'm not a fan of pudding in general-- the texture throws me off. And cash only?!

Nonetheless, I'll definitely be back. For $1.50 per macaroon, I'd definitely come back to get a box of all flavors offered for the day. Incredible!
name: Audabon Bakeshop
categories: Desserts, Bakeries, Food, Caterers, Event Planning & Services

text:
I enjoyed their ice cream way more then Ben & Jerry's just down the block.  The ice cream tasted better and was cheaper than B&Js plus it had 3 toppings added for free.  I ordered the black sesame vanilla with strawberry, lychee & mochi.  They also offer smoothies and bubble teas. 
 They looked great.
name: Snow Factory
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
Cool unique place. Its a casual dining setting, coffee shop and ice cream all in one. Indoor seating only. 
Cant comment on food but the coffee was definitely great. We also tried the ice cream, that was delicious. Flavors such as black sesame, rice, etc it was really good, creamy and you get to add all your toppings in a Chinese food togo container. Not too sweet which was good.
name: Dart Coffee Co
categories: Food, Coffee Roasteries, Coffee & Tea

text:
I was so ecstatic that a Thai rolled ice cream style shop opened on the Loop in St. Louis. I never would have dreamed that this would happen. I don't even know of any in the area back home near my suburb of Los Angeles. Basically, this is BIG news. Everyone get excited please. 

I read an article online that a senior at UMSL recently opened this store with a vision for desserts from Asia. I think he pretty much hit the spot. When I first walked in, I was very impressed with the overall ambiance of the store, the Pintrest-like seating and lighting fixtures, all the white space, cool decorations, open glass ice cream stations to watch your creation being made in front of you, etc. The only thing I didn't like was the blasting of the music. It was a little absurdly loud, but that may change in the future. 

I looked at the array of ice cream flavors, and instantly my eyes lit up at matcha, taro, black sesame, etc. Flavors I love, but don't see done well in St. Louis very much. I ended up choosing the taro flavor with strawberries, pocky, and mochi. It was around $7 plus tax. A little pricey, but my wallet can handle this every once in awhile.

I was so happy when I got my creation. The taro was so real, with actual chunks of taro. It made me want to cry tears of happiness for my taste buds. Thank you Snow Factory for not giving me fake taro powdered flavoring. My ice cream rolls were pretty dense and filling, and I had a pretty good amount of toppings. Get the taro if you are a taro lover like me!! It's fantastic.

Overall, so happy about Snow Factory opening up. Great location, great set-up inside, super innovative in bringing this dessert trend to St. Louis already, and great execution so far. I am sure they will only get better with time and experience too.
name: Snow Factory
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: Vegan doughnuts for, well, vegans or those allergic to eggs.  These are not your momma's doughnuts.  These are super huge and w designer flavours like blueberry lavender, black sesame mango, peach twist and an apple and cranberry fritter.  We made it ten minutes to closing and scored the last lavender doughnuts.  Totally worth the last minute dash!
name: Doughnut Party
categories: Food, Coffee & Tea, Donuts, Bakeries

text:
Two words: BRICK. TOAST.

I first went to Audabon to check out its selection of macarons and try its salted caramel pudding, but I made a very wise decision that day to also order a mini brick toast. The "mini" brick toast was anything but small: it was enough to feed me and my friend. That day it came with matcha ice cream, pastry cream, and pocky sticks with some blackberries on top. My friend and I loved it so much we had to go to Audabon again when we found out from Audabon's Facebook page that the brick toast flavor had changed to nutella pastry cream, salted caramel ice cream, and strawberries. I loved everything on this second toast and consequently fell head over heels for Audabon.

While so far I haven't had a macaron flavor that I dislike from Audabon, I must say the size of Audabon's macarons is smaller than Sugar Philly Truck. The salted caramel pudding was good, but it was so rich and sweet it became too much for me after eating only half of it. I have yet to try a black sesame panna cotta and matcha oreo mousse, so those two are my next conquests.

I like how cute the interior is and the free wifi, but there is one drawback to Audabon: it doesn't have a restroom for customers. One would assume that it would since Audabon serves coffee...
name: Audabon Bakeshop
categories: Desserts, Bakeries, Food, Caterers, Event Planning & Services

text: Cool new gourmet donut shop in YEG! Been wanting to try this place for a while.  The interior is nice, bright and modern.  Their mascot is this cute, what I presume to be a donut, character which will be a hit with the little ones. But the donuts are the star of the show of course. We had the cardamom rose apple fritter, passion fruit black sesame caramel, and breakfast smoothie. Deliciously unique.  The donut itself is soft and fluffy on the inside, and the icing had nice, bold flavouring. Be prepared to line up though...this place is popular. We paid $3.50 a donut, but they are quite large.
name: Doughnut Party
categories: Food, Coffee & Tea, Donuts, Bakeries

text:
I've been going to this bakery for years (about almost a decade long!!!) and the owners of the bakery are good friends of my parents and I've actually taught their kids in summer camp for a while so I've seen them grow up, which is crazy for me.  They are so sweet and kind to their customers and I just love that family-owned vibe that you don't get at these mainstream bubble tea places like Kung Fu or Tea Do. 

I love their traditional bakery goods (most under a $1!!!). I would recommend trying their: pineapple buns, hot dog buns, ham and egg buns, and roast pork buns--everything is super cheap so don't worry about breaking the bank for these treats.  

If you are in the mood for bubble tea or smoothies then you can never go wrong with their fruit smoothies, but I personally love their natural black sesame tea for $2.00 (can get it cold or warm), which is hard to find anywhere else so I always get it when I come back to Philly Chinatown.

***Note: This place is cash only!
name: Greenland Tea House
categories: Food, Tea Rooms, Coffee & Tea, Bakeries

text:
I'll give this place 5 stars. 

The facebook and philly asian community was buzzing about Audabon Bakeshop over the weekend. i was like "Audabon NJ???" Yeah...I didn't know who she was..

Made my way over on Sunday late afternoon (5pm'ish) Sold out. It's alright...i'll come back when they restock Wed. I actually came for the pull up contest but just had a big lunch, so I didn't attempt it. And 25 was a bit out of my range...lower it to 20 maybe? 

Came back Wed. night around 7pm, luckily there were some left. Ordered two of each (12 total) I was a little surprised there was no discount on anything over 5 macarons, but at $1.50...i think it's already cheap for something that can be rated "BEST IN PHILLY". After all, they have rent and utilities to pay for now at their physical bakery. I also got the new black sesame pudding thing too. At $5, i thought it was pricey. lol.

I think the location also messes with my perception of the products prices. Since it is located in Chinatown, I want to automatically assume its going to be "cheap" and filling. It isn't...it isn't expensive either. These are luxury items and the price reflects the quality and skill. At $1.50 for one (and no discount for large numbers purchased), I think they are reasonable. Are they an everyday treat like your morning coffee? I dont' think so...A quick stop after dim sum on Sundays? Sure.. perfect treat. The place is pretty spacious with some seating on the right. Not sure if they sell coffee or not, which i think Chinatown needs a coffee house since they are being overrun by tea-houses...

I can only rate the taste of the salted caramel macaron and the black sesame pudding. I'm not a big fan of macaron or sweet treats to begin with, but one bite of the salted caramel macaron was pretty good. There were layers of flavor that hit your taste buds..There was just enough sweet, just enough salt, just enough "MmMm". It was light, chewy, and  an enjoyable bite overall. The black sesame pudding was very decadent. I was full from dinner, but had 2 spoon fulls of the pudding and the flavor was pretty unique. Its not sweet, i'd even say bland (not in a bad way), but the nutty flavor and almost gritty texture from the sesame specs was nice. I don't see this being a big hit to non-Asians as the flavor is foreign to most people..I liked it. Reminded me of Mitsuwa's black sesame ice cream. (which is the reason i bought the pudding). 

I will update my review when i try the other flavors.

**UPDATE**

Tried the lemon and coffee flavors last night. They were pretty good too. The flavors aren't overwhelming and the texture and airiness of the macaron was great. Oh, the black sesame wasn't a pudding, i forgot it was a custard lol. After eating it some more, i do really like it. I still believe it won't be a big hit with non-asians bc of the flavor profile/texture. I think what sets these macarons apart from others are the consistency in the size/shape/flavor. The cream filling is really good, although it was on the border of "too sweet" for me.. but that's because i'm not a sweets person. But overall, these are pretty amazing luxury items.
name: Audabon Bakeshop
categories: Desserts, Bakeries, Food, Caterers, Event Planning & Services

text:
dear audrey,

it was like a year and a half ago.. my boyfriend came home and handed me some macarons b/c he knew i love that stuff~ and the first moment i popped your macarons in my mouth, i knew it was something amazing and i COULD NOT wait to try more flavors!! ( btw the goat cheese and popcorn ( i think) blew me out of the water!  probably b/c i didn't expect i would like it.. but i ended up LOVE LOVE LOVING IT!!!)

so after my first experience with your lovely treats, i had to go for more! conveniently, i work in center city so i could go explore and stop by your shop basically on any given day~  i followed your cute little cartoon map at the time and took my first trip to the suburban station looking for your spot~ ... couldn't find it.  went again the day after.. still couldn't find it.. i gave it another try-- going deeper into the station and looking at EVERY direction... still saw no sign of your shop.. i was sad.. it was almost like being told of a rabbit hole that i couldn't go down into the magical wonderland.. 

but just earlier this week, a friend told me about this new macaron shop that opened up in chinatown and as soon as my friend mentioned your name.  i was like THAT"S THE ONE!!! and i knew i had to pay you guys a visit a-sap! i grabbed every flavor you guys offered! kinda sad there weren't more.. but i'll be patient! nbd :)  also tried the black sesame pudding~ freakin' fabulous!! love the flavor with your own twist and recipe!!  i don't even have a sweet tooth and im contemplating about trying another one today :]

definitely looking forward to what else you guys have to offer!  so far, your macarons are THE BEST i've ever come across!!  i know i haven't tried too many kinds to give a fair judgement, but i am ecstatic that your new shop is easy to find in chinatown!! don't worry, i am spreading the word and i will be back very soon!

best,
kelly
name: Audabon Bakeshop
categories: Desserts, Bakeries, Food, Caterers, Event Planning & Services

text:
Nathaniel Reid Bakery is so special! No wonder they've won so many awards! I stopped in for the first time and picked up a Smoked Ham & Gruyère Croissant, a Kouign-Amann (pronounced "queen" ah-mahn), and a spring seasonal delicacy: the Margo. Everything was absolutely incredible! It's clear that time, energy, and (most of all) skill goes into the creation of each and every one of these materpieces.

The ham and gruyère croissant was tender ham and melty gruyère cheese with tangy dijon encased in a buttery, flaky, freshly baked croissant (even a hint warm still from the oven!) The top of the croissant had a sprinkle of white and black sesame seeds, poppy seeds, and sunflower seeds. At $4.50, it tasted FAR better than any breakfast sandwich you could get anywhere else. The Kouign-Amann is a denser croissant dough covered in a sweet, crunchy, caramelized glaze that creates a perfect balance with the soft dough interior. Now for their true show of skill: the Margo pastry. The Margo is crafted with strawberry chantilly and raspberry-lemon verbena confit, garnished with fresh raspberries that are dusted with powdered sugar, and sandwiched between two fresh french macaron cookies. Delicate, fruity, and the epitome of spring. Not to mention, the staff is SO friendly! Nathaniel Reid is an experience that should not be missed!
name: Nathaniel Reid Bakery

text:
The most aesthetically pleasing dessert cafe has just opened up in downtown Edmonton! Straight out of a perfect Instagram shot, Cacao 70 has brought its delicious dessert creations here. If you haven't heard of Cacao 70, it's a dessert chain based in Montreal that has expanded throughout Canada. Cacao 70 is well known for their decadent chocolate, such as fondues and hot chocolates. Since the chain has different concepts, the location I visited was their Sweet House concept which serves all-day brunch, dessert, and chocolate drinks. The dessert menu consists of waffles, fondues, crepes, dessert pizzas, and sharing plates. You can also get their signature dipped ice cream and chocolate drinks, available on the go.

This is their first Edmonton location, which is in the back of the Edmonton Tower in the Ice District. Two more locations are planned - one in West Edmonton Mall and the other on Whyte Ave.

My friend and I tried out their fondue and a classic waffle combo. Each of their fondue comes in two sizes and there are so many flavours to choose from! We settled on the smaller size of their matcha chocolate fondue, which was perfect for 2 people. Their other flavours are classic, black & white, triple, coffee, peanut butter, and Earl Grey. The fondue was served with fresh fruit, chocolate brownie pieces, and waffle bites. The matcha fondue itself was creamy and definitely did not lack the matcha taste. It wasn't bitter due to the balance of the chocolate but it was soooo good. I would definitely recommend trying this if you like matcha! They also have a classic waffle with their matcha chocolate called the Catcha Matcha which I'm probably gonna try on my next visit.

Their classic waffle combo definitely did not look like your average dessert waffle. We tried The Blackjack which had a Cacao 70 waffle hidden at the bottom, topped with black sesame chocolate, cheesecake creme brulee, soft serve ice cream, whipped cream, sesame seeds, and a waffle cone. Their Cacao 70 waffle had a slight crisp to it, which paired perfectly with the sesame chocolate and ice cream. I tried to get a bit of everything in each bite. Honestly, I couldn't tell where the cheesecake creme brulee was in this but I think I tasted it?? My friend and I both enjoyed The Blackjack even though it looked overwhelming at first!

Cacao 70 satisfied my sweet tooth for sure! I felt like I wasn't even in Edmonton when I was eating there.
name: Cacao 70 Sweet House

text:
First, know this: macarons are not macaroons. Look up the difference if you are intrigued.

I discovered Audabon macarons a long time ago at a coffee shop near South street where I had the salted caramel and was floored by how good it was. Fast forward a year or so and I happen to walk by a new, nice looking bakery after lunch in Chinatown so I stopped in out of curiosity. Lo and behold the same macarons from that coffee shop were now being sold in their own store and I was super excited to try them out. I can't remember all the flavors but they're amazing. My friend and I got all 6 that they had and tried them all. I think they were something like thai tea, key lime pie, miso caramel, bananas foster, black sesame, and raspberry something. AMAZING I TELL YOU. Like heaven. In Chinatown.
name: Audabon Bakeshop
categories: Desserts, Bakeries, Food, Caterers, Event Planning & Services

text:
Restaurant as part of (or connected) to the Best Western Hotel in Santa Barbara on Bath Street (which I hear is very nice, by the way).  You won't have any trouble finding parking here, so no hubbub or chaotic mess from State Street.  It's a cute place that features an enclosed patio setting.

It has a little of everything on the breakfast, lunch, and dinner menus.  But the uniqueness comes from the owner that brings a Polynesian/Hawaiian influence.  Want some Kahlua Pork?  Come here.  Want some Spam & Eggs?  Come here.  Want some Bacon Fried Rice?  Yep, come here.

PACIFIC RIM BACON FRIED RICE
============================
Made with mixed veggies, brown rice, avocado, green onion, black sesame seeds and a sunny side up egg for $10 -- this sounded really good.  Nice presentation for a very large portion, I ate half and took home the rest.  Execution?  Well, carrots, peas, and green beans from a bag out of the freezer took away from the healthy side of town, but the bacon was tasty.  (4.0 stars)

FINCHES
========
A very large bird aviary with about 100 Finches is directly connected to the restaurant.  So very cute, and not served on the menu.

OVERALL
========
The service is cordial, friendly, polite, and very accommodating.  It's a no-brainer if you are staying at the hotel to grab a convenient meal or two during your stay, but I wouldn't go out of my way to come here.
name: Live Oak Cafe

text:
First try this hot dessert place with many different items...the guy was friendly but food was very disappointed to us. Unfortunately, store name sounds like a nice dessert place in HK to me..
We ordered togo with two red bean dessert..it's just translucent sugar water filled with half tub of red bean shells and no beans inside. Tofu fai was fresh from a hot stainless pot..ok but not smooth...Black sesame dessert was also watery too..it's a little better than the red bean dessert. Two orders of sticky rice rolls..its filling like nothing but a small strip of fried donut n a little pork sung rolled with lot of rice..two veggies/pork steam buns..each with small reddish meat filling and a large bun..just wonder how ppl rated 4 or 5 stars..unless some improvements, we will not go back again:(

text:
Yummy Yummy Yume! Proximity to my office and delicious food, have me frequenting Yume often. I prefer to sit at the sushi bar and interact with their talented sushi chefs. Shout out to Chef Felix, my favorite, who takes the time to get to know his regulars and their palettes. He makes perfect recommendations based on my tastes and is up for creating custom rolls if guests are in the mood for something that is not on the menu. 

Since my original reviews, here are a few other menu items that I highly recommend:

Chili Poppers: Made to order Tempura Battered Jalapeños stuffed with Crab, Spicy Tuna and Cream Cheese, flash fried and finished with a Masago garnish and Cilantro Wasabi Crema. So good! Pro tip: Ask for a side of Eel Sauce for dipping. Sweet & Spicy is the perfect combo. 

Mike Dancing Pants Roll: Spicy crab meat, avocado, asparagus & shrimp topped with seared sea scallop & special house sauce (I recommend substituting the shrimp for tempura shrimp to add a little texture and crunch to the roll).

Popcorn Shrimp: deep fried shrimp tossed with spicy mayo sauce and garnished with black sesame seeds and green onion. Phenomenal!

Chips on Fire: tempura shiso leaf, topped with spicy tuna, green onion, masago, cilantro & wasabi sauce

Fish Mint Chip w/ Yellow Tail: tempura minced yellow tail & shiso leaf, served with ponzu sesame dressing, green onion & masago
name: Yume Sushi Japanese Restaurant

text:
So I was at a retreat and wanted a walk and lunch. A few blocks away was a Cafe - Live Oak. - Looked like a good choice, so I hoofed it over to Live Oak Cafe and am I glad I did. Even though my lunch was very simple, a hamburger (their Live Oak Burger) and a simple salad (cucumber and carrot and black sesame seeds), everything was flavorful, tasty, well presented, and just plain yummy. 
The facility is ultra clean. The floors simply shine, and everything is all so clean and inviting. 
The service was prompt, and delightful.
This is a wonderful place for lunch, and I now have it on my 'lets go back' list.

text:
Thuy Café is an adorable little coffee and bubble tea shop that mixes up some sweet concoctions.  The interior is a shade of light jade with bamboo floors and futuristic lounge furniture, and Vietnamese music videos or live concerts on the flat screen television.  
They have two sizes of bubble tea Small (around $3.50) and Large ($4.50).  The owner is usually there to take your orders and is very nice and helpful if there are any questions.  Most of the bubble teas are blended (like a milkshake) and have a milk tea base.   However, unlike some other places that have bubble tea there are actual ingredients included aside from the mix.  For example: my Sesame Tea had ground black sesame seeds mixed in and my Avocado Smoothie had real Florida Avocado blended in with vanilla.  Delicious!  The teas here are referred to as "neutral," which means not too sweet, just right.  
They also make fresh squeezed Sugarcane Juice from canes that are in the glass case refrigerator by the counter.  
Their snacks are excellent and I recommend the Grilled Pork Bahn Mi ($3.50), crisp French bread filled with grilled marinated pork, picked radish and carrot, fresh cilantro, and garlic mayo wrapped up tight in wax paper with a green Thai chili pepper on the side.
This is the best place for bubble tea and Vietnamese snacks in St. Petersburg that I have found so far.  I think the only other place that has bubble tea is in Tyrone Mall, and it was pretty weak (tried it twice out of convenience).

text:
I think I might have just found out how I'm going to carbo load for the Philly marathon. These might actually be the best bagels I've ever had in Philly. (I know. It's a strong assertion.)  I actually didn't get to go to the store itself, but my coworker brought a bunch in for a taste test. We got to try the Porcini, the Moroccan Spiced Apricot, the Black Sesame, and the Poppy. Seriously, these bagels are exactly what I look for - super soft and fluffy in the middle, with a nice tough exterior. (Fat kid alert.) The Moroccan Spiced Apricot was probably my favorite because it was so unique - sweet, but not too sweet (And I'm one of those people who hates sweet things mixed in with savory. So you know this was good!). I was honestly a little disappointed in the Porcini. I didn't get much of a Porcini flavor from it and we all thought it tasted more like Pumpernickel. I only got to try the plain cream cheese, but I can't wait to go back and try some of the flavored ones. (Kimchee cream cheese and Lemon Goat Cheese Spread? Yes please!) 

 So, in short, go to Knead. Now! Unless it's after 2 pm. Then go tomorrow.
name: Knead Bagels

text:
Philly has overpriced Montreal-style bagels, chain bagel stores that always leave you wanting more cream cheese, and plenty of places that recommend toasting the bagel to ensure the best taste. I've been waiting for someone to bring good bagels to Center City and Knead Bagels leaves me waiting no longer. 

I came here on a Saturday morning around 10:30 and was surprised it wasn't a mob scene. I love that they offer both traditional and non-traditional bagels and cream cheese flavors. I tried the black sesame bagel with kimchee cream cheese and Dining Partner had an everything bagel with lox, onion, cucumber and plain cream cheese. The bagels were incredibly soft and fresh. After we devoured our bagels, we also both split another everything bagel with plain cream cheese. The bagels were a good size and they didn't even come close to skimping on the cream cheese. I ended up buying a half dozen to take home and they even included a freezer bag. Fast friendly service at the counter, reasonably priced, and now officially my go-to bagel spot in Philadelphia.

text:
I have a close place to my heart all foods Asian; be it Cantonese, Japanese fish, Thai, Malaysian and one of my favorites Korean.

What is there not to love about KOREAN food? When done well it tends to have all the perfect elements of the perfect meal.

Take KTown BBQ for instance, as soon as you walk into the door you know you are in for a treat. Your nostrils instantly pick up the aroma of grilled short ribs that have been marinating in special spices for over 24 hours.

Not trying to b racist or one of those other types but you know this the real deal with so many Korean families having lunch here. It is what it is. Its not Americanized and I luv that.

KTown is sort of a mini chain, Sammy Chon has become a pillar of the Korean Community in Philly and he has been able to spread his love across the Delaware into NJ.

He happens to be the creator of the famed Koagie (listed as one of the best sandwiches in America) http://www.endlesssimmer.com/2011/02/28/americas-best-new-sandwiches-part-2/

The take the hoagie tradition of Philly and stuff a bit of Korea into it, literally. Think bulgogi, sesame slaw. Amazing.

I was contemplating having one of those today (9-4-13) But after reviewing the menu and locking my eyes on LA Kalbi I knew instantly what I needed to order.

Shortly after I placed my order a complimentary set of ban-chan was brought to my table. For those that are wondering what that is, its basically small side dishes that complement the main course. Usually anywhere between 6 to 8 small dishes of various flavors that run the gamut from pickled to spicy to sweet all intended to compliment the flavors of the main course.

The LA Kalbi came out shortly after. And boy was it amazing. Some of the best I've had around.

Extremely tender and full of flavor which ranged from garlic, sesame, ginger, scallion and soy. Simply amazing esp the areas that had a bit of char close to the bone. Bliss!!!

The bento lunch also cam with a side of rice topped with black sesame. A sesame salad with various greens. Vermacelli noodles with beef and a side of radish.

Overall the meal was totally amazing and very generous. K cant wait to return. Please see pictures.
name: Dolsot House

text:
I woke up yesterday and decided I needed some bagels.  This place was the closest.  It is definitely not for traditionalists.  The bagels are quite good though, as are the egg sandwiches etc.  One issue that almost lost them a star:  poppyseed bagels and not sesame bagels!!  I ordered my egg sandwich on a sesame bagel, and it came on a poppyseed bagel.  Ok, I thought, maybe I made a mistake or was misheard.  But then I opened the bagel bag this morning (I had ordered half-dozen), and in place of the two sesame bagels I ordered were two poppy.  I hate poppyseed bagels, so i know it wasn't me.  Have to edit this - my wife pointed out that they were black sesame seeds on the bagel.  This doesn't make things better - to me, a sesame bagel is a sesame bagel - no need to fix what works!
I'm editing this to give it five stars - I subtracted one because of the sesame seed issue.  The owner contacted me, was very nice and offered to give me free replacement bagels the next time I come in.  That is great customer relations.
name: Knead Bagels

text: They have a large selection of flavors for macarons. It was my first time here today and I wanted to try half the flavors they offer. I ask for the recommendation of the staff but he was very blunt telling me that different people have different taste and that is true. He did recommend me the black sesame and peanut dark chocolate after asking me what types of food I like to eat. I got mostly dark chocolate related macarons because I'm a huge fan of chocolate. The black sesame macaron was the macaron that I saw on Yelp that made me decide to make a visit and I am glad I did. I recommend the black sesame for people to try and as well as lemon. Normally when I get lemon macarons it is either really sour or contains poppy seed, but the lemon macaron here is very refreshing

Next time I visit, I want to try the kimchi cream cheese with black sesame bagel. Something unordinary but can totally rock your socks off.

text:
So excited Clementine's came to my neighborhood! I have been to their Lafayette Square location as well. Same great quality came with them to this locale.

Fun flavors, cute interior, delicious cones. I would give five stars, but they were out of five flavors! All the ones I wanted. I was disappointed. Luckily, they have no shortage of goodness, and I ended up loving both the vanilla and black sesame. Highly recommend both, but hope next time I go they are better stocked.

text:
Knead Bagels is my favorite breakfast spot in the area. The bagels are better than any I've ever had, soft, flavorful, and unique. The cream cheese flavors are just a good and if you're vegan, they even have hummus for you! So far I've tried the black sesame bagel with scallion cream cheese and bacon, egg, & cheese on a togarashi. ALL DELICIOUS. 

I plan on coming back for a morning special with some coffee as often as my budget will allow. :)

text: I've only been living and working in Philly for about a month and am already addicted to Knead!!  My coworkers introduced me and I am hooked!!  So far I've tried the lavender with vanilla honey and the black sesame with poblano.  Both are tasty!  The lavender with vanilla honey is not too sweet, just the way I like.  I've also had the chicken salad sandwich, which was good.  Also, the salad is a must have!!  I was so sad today when my coworker reminded me that Knead is closed on Mondays--can't wait to get my fix!!

text: There aren't a ton of bagel shops in Philadelphia and I was excited to find this shop on my way to work. They aren't open Mondays which was weird to me since I feel more prone to buy breakfast on Mondays to make the best out of the beginning of the work week. They have different flavors of bagels that you wouldn't find in other shops, the only "traditional" flavors were plain and poppy seed. They serve drinks but nothing special - coffee, tea, iced tea, orange juice. I got the black sesame seed bacon egg and cheese sandwich. They put an aioli on the sandwich which is interesting...not sure if I like it, the flavor kind of overpowers the sandwich. My biggest issue is the price, it was $7 just for the sandwich. I can walk across the street and get a drink and breakfast sandwich for the same price at Starbucks. I regret getting black sesame seed and I wish it was traditional sesame seed since they already have poppy seed. The seeds get stuck easily in your teeth so bring floss! The sandwich was fine, just not worth the cost and will keep me from going back.
name: Knead Bagels

text:
We literally just left this cafe a minute ago. First off, the ambience is very homey. We got inside and was greeted right away who I believe may be the owner. They had a range of flavors and was $2 per macaron which is a reasonable price. Picked out 8 for to go and 4 to snack inside. 

I've had my fair share of macarons and ICI's were perfect for my liking. Not too sweet but was filled with so much flavor. My favorite was the Black Sesame. My boyfriend also had the ice coffee which was pretty good. On our way out, I couldn't resist but buy another box of 8 with different flavors from the first. 

Overall, I see myself visiting ICI whenever I'm back in Philly again.

text:
Knead is the bomb. Plenty of vegetarian and some vegan options. Their cream cheese is so good that I've never actually gotten an egg sandwich - just a bagel with cream cheese :)

My favorites are the fennel and sea salt bagel with roasted tomato cream cheese and the black sesame bagel with sweet potato curry cream cheese. They also have some salads and bagel banh mi.

 Plus, the staff is so nice! Just be sure to get there early - they close at 2:00pm.

text:
This shop has a fun and adventurous variety of bagels and cream cheese spreads, such as black sesame with potato curry or lavender with vanilla honey. They also have a lot of different sandwiches if youre looking for something heavier. 
I went for the first time today and got a togarashi bagel with scallion lime cream cheese..it was so good! It wasn't spicy at all. Usually i scrape off a lot of cream cheese because i always feel it's too much, but today i had every bite! My friend got a coriander bagel with jalapeno cream cheese, which was also really good! Definitely will be going again.

text:
so today, not only did i notice the new cone flavors (chocolate chip, rainbow cookie, chocolate, and pretzel) they had caramel bacon gelato... i tried the chai and it was pretty good, but the taste of caramel and the texture of tiny bits of bacon were too good to pass up.. so 5 stars for the caramel bacon on a pretzel cone... sweet n salty... they threw in a small tub of black sesame since it was one of the flavors i suggested.... 

my wife liked the honey almond, but she had the nutella affogato... affogato is just gelato with espresso served in a glass lined with caramel or chocolate topped with whipped cream...

there were about 4 other groups of ppl there.. other customers have also been suggesting their flavors... sounds like this place is doing well... in the near future, lunch options from SUP and extended hours...  

me + no iphone = 3 check ins here
name: Bijous Yogurt & Gelato Kafe
categories: Restaurants, Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts

text:
Delicious! Had a bacon egg and cheese on a plain bagel and it was one of the best bacon egg and cheese iv ever had! They put an aioli on it and it was amazzzzzzzing! Bagel was perfect- crispy soft doughy all at once. I do Wish the bacon was a touch crispier though. Also had black sesame and kimchee cream cheese, which was good but I'd probably skip the kimchee cc next time. Can't talk about wait times as I was there at 630am and no one else was there so it was relatively quick. The woman taking my order left a little to be desired- kind of stared at me like deer in headlights. The coffee she gave me had grounds in it so I just asked for a latte instead- more blank stares. Luckily another woman (manager? Owner?) came over and was extremely friendly and gave me the latte free of charge.

Can't wait to go back!! Maybe you guys should consider local delivery to Pennsylvania hospital ?!?

text:
I have a meeting in center city this morning, so I figured that I would try this bagel shop/cafe. I am glad that I did. This shop has interesting bagel (black sesame seed- which is an unprocessed sesame seed, fennel seed, and lavender just to name a few) selection and a wide variety of toppings (flavored cream cheeses, many began options, eggs/meats, etc.). 

I went with the traditional choice of an everything bagel with roasted veggie cream cheese. The bagel is delicious, just the right consistency. The bagel was rolled in the sesame and poppy seeds, onion, garlic, etc., so the top and bottom of the bagel both have flavor (yay!). The roasted veggie cream cheese has a savory flavor but doesn't have a strong veggie flavor. The coffee is standard. Morning happy hour (until 8:30) gets you a coffee and bagel with cream cheese for $5 and change. 

The shop has a relaxed cafe ambience, with 4 high tops and 4 regular tables (each seating 2) inside plus a few outside tables. The kitchen and seating area is clean. The staff is pleasant, the service is fast, and the food is fresh. 

This is one of the best bagels that I have gotten outside of NY (and probably the best one that I've had in Philly). If I have another meeting in this area, I will be back to try one of their more eclectic recommended menu items.

text:
If you're in search of stand out and unique bagels and cream cheese, then you KNEAD to check this place out!

The bagels are baked fresh throughout the day, so they don't recommend  toasting the bagels (but will if you ask). 

The togarashi bagel had a hint of spice from the dried chili peppers and paired perfectly with the scallion lime cream cheese. They definitely didn't skimp on the herbs, and I loved the bright citrus note!

The black sesame bagel was a standout with its cherry pepper and prosciutto cream cheese. This is one of the most unique cream cheeses I've ever tasted, perfectly blending both savory and spicy ingredients!

I would order these two bagels again in a heartbeat and wish I lived closer to frequent this bagel shop more often!

text:
Amazing fresh bagels that are perfectly toasted yet soft and full of flavor: that's what Knead delivers. I came on a Saturday morning to pick up a dozen of bagels for a coworkers meeting for $13. I asked for a variety and we got black sesame, everything,  poppy seed, fennel seed & sea salt, flax & togarashi (which is actually spicy...yaass). I picked the garden vegetable cream cheese and the lady recommend the vanilla honey as well for a savory and sweet option. They were about  $6.50 / half pint, not $3.00 which was not written clearly on the blackboard (it threw me off guard when my total was $27).

The service was quick, 5 minutes and I was out. Everyone at the meeting loved the bagels and couldn't stop eating them. The cream cheese qas so delicious that I wish I wasn't so full so that I could continue eating.
Definitely try this place !!
I am going to give the lavender a try next time :)

text:
so as a born and bred NY'er i am picky about 2 foods- bagels and pizza...

While the bread factor on Kneads bagels cannot beat NYs bagels, I have to give props to their creative spreads and bagels. 
I walked in there prepared to be wowed, because their choices are different! Sweet potato curry CC, lime bagels, togashri and black sesame... the varieties are intriguing.
the bagels and CCprice is pretty steep, at 3.50- but well worth a try..
Not as big as the NY bagel but the amount of CC they put on the bagel is filling.

Come for a bagel and sit out in the park across the street. They offer seating at Knead as well.

text:
I'd been hearing a lot about this place and had been wanting to stop in and try it. 
We both liked the decor of the place. It almost had a steampunk-vibe. We both had appetizers (my fiancee had the cornbread; I had the deviled eggs.) While the eggs were tasty, I nabbed a couple fork-fulls of cornbread and wished I'd gotten that one like I started to. I absolutely love cornbread and the jalapeno butter they used was a nice flavorful touch. It also wasn't overly spicy, which I liked.

For entrees, she got the salmon and I opted for scallops. I can't really tell anymore if scallops are indicative of what a restaurant as a whole can do from a culinary standpoint because I feel like scallops are really hard to mess up. I always worry that the scallops won't be very filling but my concerns proved to be unfounded. The dish was filled with great vegetable choices and a smear of squash puree. I ate everything on my plate. So good. I tried a little bit of my fiancee's salmon dish and wasn't that impressed. If I remember correctly, it was seared with black sesame so one side looked like it had been dipped in tar. To be honest, it kind of tasted like it was a little on the burnt side. Glad I chose the scallops in this case because I think the salmon was in my top 3 choices when ordering. However, my fiancee LOVED the salmon totally, so different strokes on that one. 

Speaking of ordering, our server wasn't that great. When I was deliberating which one of two entrees I was considering, he was kind of flippant in his response and I could tell the last thing he wished to do was actually offer his opinion on a dish so I chose the scallops. But throughout the night, he hardly said anything. Never asked how we were doing. Didn't ask if we wanted dessert, just threw the menu down and strolled off. 

If there was a way we could have tipped the kitchen and not him, I would have done it. 

Overall, the food was fantastic and I would like to go back again and try a different entree this time. Hopefully we wouldn't get the same server because that guy was pretty crappy.

text:
I enjoyed Knead Bagels. Yes, the wait can be a bit long and yes they do run out of bagels by late afternoon.
There's a wide assortment of cream cheese that I have to try. I only had the plan so far and it was thick and creamy.
Everything bagel is awesome. So is garlic and black sesame. The bagels are dense and moist as they should be.
I had one of the breakfast sandwiches that had turkey sausage and egg, which I thought was very good.
Service was friendly. I would return.

text:
Probably my new favorite place for tea time! This place is the newest place to check out and I highly recommend. It is decorated beautifully with elegant chandeliers and clean decor. They played soft music in the background, further adding to the soothing ambiance. 

The wait staff was very attentive so we were able to order quickly after we decided what we wanted.

We ordered a jasmine green tea, which was perfect since it was quite chilly that day. My mom has high standards for teas and this one passes the mark! We also ordered the Trio with Black Sesame Creme brûlée, Green tea fancier, and the Fruit Tart. 

The black sesame creme brûlée was DELISH. Not too sweet but strong black sesame flAvor - definitely interesting and unique.  

Green Tea Fancier was great! Reminiscent of a green tea muffin, which a slightly crisp muffin top but soft pillowy inside. 

Fruit tart wasn't too sweet. The cream didn't have too much flavor and acted more as a vessel to highlight the fruit. It was good but nothing to put in the books. 

We also ordered the purple yam soufflé, which was incredibly moist, making it taste like a yam but in muffin form. The ice cream added just the right amount of sweetness and added sharp juxtaposition between the soufflé in the hot ramekin and the cold ice cream.

text:
Knead bagels... what can I say about my favorite Philly spot? I'm leaving Philly and I will miss Knead Bagels every day I'm gone. Knead is known for their excellent quality bagels with interesting and unconventional flavor combinations and their wonderful staff. I started going to Knead back in 2014 and my favorite was the black sesame bagel with kimchi cream cheese. Since then I have discovered the beauty of their weekly specials which are simply put, special! The specials can be sweet, savory, or anything in between. It always fun to order the special bagel and cream cheese combo just to see how delicious it will be. I also love the togarashi with scallion lime cream cheese (which I've also started adding a pickled green tomato to at the suggestion of my friend). The spicy togarashi with the sharp but cooling cream cheese is too good. I will also deeply miss the chicken salad sandwhich and tuna salad sandwhich, both of which are so creative and flavorful. The chicken salad is so fresh and there are never any bites of gristle (I'm a big texture person). 

Finally, I would be remiss not to say that the staff are so wonderful and nice. It was such a nice place to visit and I will miss seeing everyone who made the experience so great.
name: Knead Bagels

text:
I would definitely come back again. 

Convenient parking: Mochi Ring is located within this plaza in Abington. That means I don't have to look for street parking if I want to go here for a quick snack/dessert. 

Clean: My first impression of this place is...it's clean. With Covid still being around, the two employees that I saw do have their masks on. However, there are no tables if you want to enjoy and eat their mochi donut or try out their drinks inside the store. 

Mochi Donuts: They taste fresh to me. There are a number of flavors to choose from. And from time to time, they will have new flavors out. The day I was there they had Ube and Mango as their new flavors. Their normal selections I believe are Strawberry, Matcha, Oreo, Nutella, Coffee, Brown Sugar Milk Tea, Black Sesame, Coconut, etc. I've tried all except Matcha. Personal preference that I would recommend is heat the mochi donut for a few seconds before eating so the texture of the mochi would be soft and chewy. 

Drinks: I ordered their Honey Citron Lemon Green Tea and their King of Oolong Milk Tea. Both drinks are yummy and delicious to me. Definitely recommend to give the drinks a try.
name: Mochi Ring Donut And Bubble Tea

text:
Lovely place for a quick bit and lot of chats. I wouldn't come if you're expecting a full meal but maybe a light bite. The do have some entrees but it's not very expansive. Their tea selection, however, is quite large.  

Tried the lavender oolong and loved it. It was light but aromatic. Quite excited to try other tea offerings. I split a teapot with my gal pal. Between us two, it was a decent amount. I think three to a pot might be a bit too little per person. Also got some fries and their dessert trio to share. The Goma (black sesame) Brulee is really good. Full of flavor, nutty and creamy. The Pâte à Choux were alright and the green tea financier is passable.

The service is quite nice. We didn't feel rushed and we enjoyed our tea time.

text:
A great spot for when you're looking for a solid ambiance and yummy desserts! 

I've tried a variety of their desserts, and haven't been disappointed so far. I think their trio set is particularly cute and flexible as you can choose from several options. I tried a goma (black sesame) crème brûlée here for the first time and really enjoyed it. 

For being a pricier place, they still have a credit card minimum of $15 or something, which can become cumbersome when you're just coming here to share a dessert. 

If you wanna let loose on your calorie count and your wallet for an occasional treat, would def recommend!

text:
In order to be a successful eating establishment, one has to excel in at least one discipline or even one item.  If I were to correlate some to celebrities, ice cream shops would be like your sweet romantic comedy actors/actresses , steakhouses would be like your meaty action stars , and food trucks would be your Indie up and comers or niche actors/actresses.  

Once in a blue moon you come across a polymath, which wikipedia defines as "a person whose expertise spans a significant number of different subject areas--such a person is known to draw on complex bodies of knowledge to solve specific problems"  The first celebrity that comes to mind is Steve Martin.   Steve Martin is not only a comedic genius, but he holds his own as a reputable banjo player in his own band and a New York Times bestselling author and playwright. 

I would consider the baker behind the counter at ICI to be a polymath considering the fact she is not French, came into the business from an accounting background, but was able to use her exacting nature to devise some of the best macarons, croissants, as well as other pastries and coffee I have come across on the East coast, considering my top beloved joints mainly lie in San Francisco, Portland, and Seattle.  

While its namesake highlight the macarons and the coffee, the unspoken star as many others have pointed out are the croissants, the cream filled cruffins, and the kouign amann.  If there was a Richter scale for the degree of shatter between the laminations of butter and pastry biting into a croissant, the croissant at ICI would register a 7.4, well worth the caloric indulgence.  The fact that the baker is Asian carries an additional infusion of sophisticated flavors-twists such as green tea, peanut-black sesame,  and lychee/mancho/passionfruit in her other creations, but the technical mastery and blueprint behind every item is still indisputably French.

To paraphrase a compliment David Chang gave to one of his favorite  Tokyo yakitori joints in his Ugly Delicious series, "The greatest compliment that I can give is that when I am eating, I am already planning in my head my next trip returning for another meal".  That is how I feel whenever I come to Philly and have the opportunity to drop in since I am already planning the next pastry I want to try on my next visit as I eat the one I just purchased.
name: ICI Macarons & Cafe

text:
This place was so cute and definitely a charming and slightly fancy place for some great tea and dessert. 

Got the Montagne Bleue tea and it was floral and fragrant for a black tea, and you could definitely taste all the different notes in it. 

For dessert, I got the sampler trio with the Goma Crème brûlée, thé éclair, and the fruit tart. The fruit tart had a nice, light flavor, but was honestly not extraordinary , so it was my least favorite out of the three. Thé éclair was perfectly balanced between flaky pastry, and the cream was subtle and don't overpower the whole dessert. My favorite was the crème brûlée - the black Sesame added an amazingly unique taste and should honestly be a staple in crème brûlée from now on. Overall, all the desserts were light and not to sweet, so you don't feel guilty about loading up on sugar. 

Overall, a super cute place to go for dessert or another special occasion!

text: I think their concept is so unique and cool. What a smart way to create your own fruit tea or milk tea flavors. The instructions are straight forward and there are a good amount of flavors to choose from. I think you can't go wrong with the fruit tea flavors. Any two flavors I picked, the finishing drink taste so good! I also enjoyed getting the black sesame and regular milk tea combined. The price is also decent. I like coming here if I am in the area! They also served some snack such as steamed buns, fries, and etc. A great place to hang out and grab a delicious fruit tea/ milk tea drink.
name: Bubblelicious Lab
categories: Food, Bubble Tea, Coffee & Tea, Desserts

text:
Early gray milk tea was a great choice. We ordered it with 80% sugar which was still a bit sweet. Might have to do 
50% sugar next time. 
The durian Mille crepe pancake was very smooth and creamy. Strong durian flavor--tasted exactly like the fruit. 
We also ordered the Trio Combo.  The black sesame creme brûlée was the best dessert out of the trio. It was creamy with a perfect flavor of black sesame. The fruit tart filling was grainy and lacked flavor. The green tea fiancier wasn't anything memorable.  I would go back for the milk tea again.

text:
One of the newest additions to Philadelphia, and it is good news. First class and top quality bagels that is still under the radar.

It was tough to choose, we were so tempted to buy a dozen of bagels, and so we did- a dozen of different varieties and we got an extra one for free.

Their bagels specialties includes black sesame, pastrami spiced, everything, poppy seed, and cardamom bagel, my favorite- that should be their calling card with the exotic flavor, absolute perfection!
Along with the insanely-good cream cheese spreads and schmears from the plain cream cheese, to the flavored ones i.e:  roasted tomato, cinnamon raisin and the scallion lime cream cheese, which was a vote-winner. If you're feeling adventurous, I suggests their smoked chopped liver cream cheese!

The bagels were rich, glossy with a golden glow, and always fresh out of the oven. Crispy and crunchy from the outside, dense and chewy from the inside- no need to be toasted and make one of the most perfect bites! What a delight! 

A swab of fresh cinnamon raisin cream cheese on a cardamom bagel bagel is hard to beat. Knead Bagels you nailed it!

Four and half Yelps!

text: I was really pleased with my visit here recently. I came, got a nice cup of black sesame ice cream and lounged on the bench seating while I breastfed my baby and enjoyed it. This shop is tiny but it has some great ice cream and the staff member who worked here when I visited was great as well. I hope to enjoy the waffle cone in the future! I don't think there's a restroom here and there really isn't much seating (an outdoor wooden bench and an indoor booth bench by the window). Still, most are likely to leave with a pint in the winter or with a cone in the summer and enjoy the delicious treats!

text:
While visiting the city we stumbled upon this place; it was busy when we arrived so we opted to order to go vs waiting 20 minutes for a table for 2.  We got the B.E.C. breakfast sandwich & a butter croissant.  We still waited 20 minutes or so for our to go order; when we got our order we just sat at a table outside as there were a few open & no one waiting for the line - some places frown upon this but the staff did not mind. 
The B.E.C. was good sized for a breakfast sandwich & one of the best breakfast sandwiches we've had.  I think the black sesame seed roll is what put the B.E.C over the top. Everything on the menu sounded good - if we are back in the area we will visit again.

text:
Got the Black Sesame bagel(supposedly with Kimchi? I may be wrong since I didn't taste any of it, and the website has not been updated..fail) with Kimchi cream cheese. Yes, I'm Korean.

The bagel, though, was a little disappointing. I didn't find anything distinct about it, and I can't even describe it. This place is not up to par with your neighborhood bagel shop in NYC (sorry if I sound like a snob...I LOVE bagels.) The Kimchi Cream Cheese was better, just enough Kimchi flavor (and actual kimchi in the spread!) with a tinge of heat.

A plus- Mighty Leaf teas!

text:
Mochi Ring Donut just opened in Jenkintown. It's tucked away in a small plaza but when you walk in, it's cute and quaint. They offer a variety of flavors of mochi donuts from coconut, nutella, strawberry, coffee, black sesame, matcha, etc. From the few that I tried, my favorite is black sesame!

The donuts taste light and fluffy, and not overly sweet. Definitely a refreshing snack/dessert. There's a parking lot outside, so plenty of space. 

They're currently offering a soft/grand opening special where you can try a free mochi donut.

text:
Tucked away in the back of Chinatown, this place looks amazing inside. Aesthetically pleasing and welcoming atmosphere. The staff was nice and efficient. 

Since my friend and I was a little hungry we went with the Chicken Katsu Sandwich was delicious. The chicken was fried nicely and still juicy inside. Nicely seasoned as well. The flavoring was on point and the sauce on the chicken was delicious. Everything is held together by a delicious butter brioche bun.

The salad on the side was well a simple salad nothing special. Not too sure what kind of dressing they used, a little similar to honey mustard taste but very mild.

Onwards to the dessert. The Purple Yam Mille Crepe Cake was pretty good. This type of flavor is usually very mild, but I felt like this one was a bit too mild in flavor. The layers itself are very nicely done and soft, piled high, and easily cut through. Still a very delicious cake.

Trio Combo Mix and Match is a great sampler platter. Very aesthetically pleasing to the eyes and pictures. The green tea financier has a hint of green tea on a soft and warm cake. Very light and slightly moist. It definitely goes well with the tea they have.

The Pate a Choux Chocolate Ice Cream was just as delicious. Very crunch pastry on top that complements the rich chocolate ice cream.

Lastly the Goma Brûlée. It might not look the most appealing, but it was delicious. It still has the nice hard caramelization on top and underneath is the black sesame filling. Delicious and smooth as it enters your mouth and coats your tongue with the flavor of black sesame. The filling is a little thick but it isn't a big deal.

In conclusion an amazing place to try different desserts. Great place for a date and a must try. Definitely can't wait to go back again.

text:
This a nice place with both indoor and outdoor seating. Nice looking interior and has that cafe atmosphere to it.

I got the everything bagel with egg, cheese, and their house Knead Aioli. This was a pretty good bagel. Soft fluffy eggs and oozy cheese is on point. The aioli was delicious and can be a bit overpowering especially so depending on the bagel you get. It was a great bagel, but I think I would prefer a different bagel with this instead of the everything bagel.

My friend got the same thing, but with the Togarashi bagel. This was a Japanese chili powder kind of bagel with some seaweed and black sesame. It was delicious and complimented the egg, cheese, and Aioli. I would 100% recommend trying it with this bagel.

Overall they have tons of options to customize your bagel. It's not expensive for some good quality food with a variety of options. A word to the wise though, for those that like a softer kind of bagel this might not be up your alley, but I still recommend giving it a try. The bagels here are on the harder side of the scale.

text:
I went to their soft opening, one of their first  customers! I am so excited about this place. 

Inside is sleek with tables and a couch. They have a few plants and decorations too. They have the clAssic  boba flavors with some unique in house drinks like the Sky Blue and Dream House Taro. The also have macaroons, cupcakes, and small cakes. Definitely a plus!!! The macaroon flavors I got were ube, green tea, black sesame and more I can't remember. The staff were really nice and helpful too. 

This is a family owned business and  I can't wait  for them to succeed and bring another boba place to the westbank!!!

text: I had the Morning Special which comes with bacon, egg, and cheese.  It was quite tasty and very affordable.  The dessert crepes looked fantastic and I'll have to go back for those soon.  I did try some of the ice cream and they had flavors that I had had never had before--both the Azuki (red bean) and Black Sesame were delicious.  I'll definitely be back!

text:
Oh emmm gee, this place is delicious. I never had donuts quite like this before. The donuts had this chewy texture to it that can't quite be described in words. We ordered a half dozen of different flavors (matcha, strawberry, black sugar, black sesame, taro, and cookies n cream). I really enjoyed them all. My daughter loved the taro one and my sisters favorite was the strawberry. 

As for bubble teas - also wow! The Boba was cooked perfectly and the drinks varieties they had were plentiful. They had something for each of my parties liking. From fruit teas to milk teas, they have it!

If this place was closer to me, I'd definitely be going every weekend lol. .

text:
I want everyone in the Philadelphia metropolitan area to descend on this place like suburban moms going to the strip mall on Black Friday morning. I want whoever is reading this to drop your phone right now, leave your house in whatever you're wearing, and hit the road. Because I want this place to become so popular that it never closes down. 

If you've never had a mochi ring donut, it's deep fried like a regular yeast donut, but made with tapioca/rice flour, which gives them a more springy consistency and slightly different flavor. (That description doesn't feel quite right... you just have to try them to understand). The icings are also better than average donut shops because they have things like yuzu, black sesame, and taro. They also have more traditional icings like strawberry or Nutella, but super-flavorful. 

To add icing to all of the icing you'll already have, they serve really great bubble tea. And corn dogs that are kind of hard to describe but you should eat them. And that's a full, balanced meal, folks.
name: Mochi Ring Donut And Bubble Tea

text: Wow! I can't believe how many different and imaginative flavors of popsicles they have here!  Unless you're Asian or super into Asian desserts, you might've never tried black sesame sweets before. My friend was super confused about her black sesame popsicle but after one bit, she was hooked!  My favorite flavors were the earl grey, chocolate nibs and hibiscus pops.  So many flavors!!! How can you ever try all of them?? My tongue would freeze over and fall off first before I got through all the awesome flavors!!

text:
Yogurtland has THE BEST plain tart and while you're at that..they also have the best pistachio flavor!  I'm so glad they finally opened up in Tucson!  

They are currently doing an "around the world" flavor fest featuring all kinds of different flavors from around the world like black sesame (a very popular ice cream flavor in east asian countries), pog juice flavor (from my original home in Hawaii), and other sorts that are worth checking out.

text:
The mango mille crepes is awesome. Definitely get this. It's served with chunks of fresh and sweet mango. Really refreshing. The matcha one is ok, you can pass on this one. We were around 2, I wanted the motchi but I was told it is available at 3. I also wanted the black sesame paste dessert but it's not available. Very disappointed .

The mango pocket is basically abig chunk of mango and whipped cream wrapped in a crepe. It's ok, nothing special.

Next time I want to try the shaved ice.
