text:
Wait--I think I actually LOVE Mopho. We waited to try it out until Mopho worked out their routine. We had actually taken them off of our list because we got some ehh reviews. What brought us in was an appetizer we had at Drafts for Crafts at the museum, which was their blue cheese and some sort of chipotle mayo with a perfectly fried oyster. Obviously that was SOOOO GOOD that we just had to go to Mopho immediately after on the following night. 

We started with the chicken wings and shrimp and pork spring rolls. The chicken wings are to die for and are fun and messy, perfectly crispy, and tossed in a sauce I wanted to bathe in. The spring rolls are probably the best I've had at a restaurant, they're perfectly wrapped and filled with a delicious fresh combo of veggies, paired with a nice thick peanut sauce. After that we ordered our entrees. I got the tofu and cauliflower rice bowl with a fried egg and it was exactly what I wanted. It was light and filling at the same time and the tofu was crunchy without being dry. I definitely will have a hard time trying anything else because it was so good that I want to order it again and again. My dad got the oyster poboy (a take on Bahn mi) but did not share a single bite because he wasn't willing to part with it. That's a lot for a man who has never really liked Vietnamese food! My mom got the duck poboy. It was amazing, and delicious, and the (rice?) chips that they're served with was a refreshing take on basic chips. 

While I wish we could have gotten desert, we were honestly too stuffed...but I'll be coming back for something that our waiter mentioned there was house made black sesame ice cream in... However, this was probably because we started with drinks. I ordered the Guns-and-Roses + Mezcal boba tea, which was the most satisfying drink I've had at a restaurant recently. Who doesn't love boba tea, ESPECIALLY when there's alcohol added to it. I can't wait to come back and try the other flavors. 

I honestly see myself coming back to Mopho a million times. Easily one of my favorite spots in the city now.
name: Mopho

text: Went in while there was a line, but got my order. The black sesame milk tea was amazing. I love that I could feel the little seeds so I know they put real sesame seeds.

text:
So glad I found another bubble tea shop in town because STL is so lacking... The decor inside is very cute and modern-looking and the staff was super friendly!Their milk teas were spot on in flavor and not sickeningly sweet. My friend got an Oreo milk tea at 50% sweetness with boba and I got black sesame milk tea at 75% with herb jelly and we were both very satisfied with them! Even though we went close to their closing time, a little after 8pm, their boba still tasted fresh. I've been to a lot of places where the boba tastes old and kind of hard close to closing. 

I also thought the price was good for the quality and quantity. I liked that they blended actual black sesame seeds in my drink instead of wimping out with a powder or something. It's one size and my drink was under $5 with no extra charge for boba, unless you want to add an additional topping for 0.50. It's not the best milk tea I've ever had, but it will be my go-to while I'm in the STL area.
name: Share Sweet
categories: Desserts, Food

text:
Four of us had lunch here recently and it was quite good.

One friend and I had the "Black & Bleu" burger, described as:
"Cajun coated and topped with crumbled bleu cheese, lettuce, tomato and
red onion. $9.99." 

Patrons are given a few choices as a side-dish, soup, salad or "twigs" (their code for French fries). I had the sweet potato fries, which were tasty but, perhaps, a little dry. 

Alas, I did not specify how I wanted the burger cooked. So, it was served a teensy overcooked for my taste but, again, I did not order it as medium-rare as I do usually. That's "My bad."

Another friend had the "C.B.L.T.A.", which has the following description:
"It sounds like a government agency but it's actually a delicious sandwich made with
chipotle bacon, lettuce, fresh sliced tomato, chipotle mayonnaise, and sliced avocado
served on classic white bread. $9.49." 

She had her C.B.L.T.A. served on sourdough bread, enjoyed it very much, and also had a mix of the "regular" French fries and sweet potato fries -- one of the side-dish options.

The fourth dish served was from the "Raw Sushi" side of the house, a Maki roll, the "California Roll."
The description for that: "Chilean rock crab, avocado, and toasted black sesame seeds. $8.00."

The place was busy at lunchtime. We had to wait at the bar for a few minutes to get a table. Meanwhile, the waiter took our drink orders and we were quickly seated. The service was friendly and efficient.

Seating is a mix of traditional tables, bar seating and booths at the rear of the restaurant. There is also outdoor seating (too cold outside the day we were there).

The décor is simple but pleasant, complete with exposed air conditioning ducts overhead. (I'm kinda "done" with that look, but it works.)

For now, I'm giving Willowcreek Grill Four Stars and may "upgrade" my rating after another meal or two there, but it will probably never make it to a "full" Five Stars; it just misses the Five Star threshold. 

I'm certainly going to return; I kinda like the place.
name: Willowcreek Grill & Raw Sushi Restaurant

text:
Really delicious. Clean, tasteful atmosphere with a great smooth vibe! 

Super friendly staff! We were seated promptly and ordered pork belly and sheimp spring rolls to share. Then my friends ordered pho and pork belly vermicelli. I had the special. It was an incredibly spicy chicken over cd vermicelli. Lots of fresh herbs, cucumber, and pepper. So delicious! 

We ended the meal with three desserts. Ginger ice cream sammys (deeeeeelish), a sponge cake with ice cream and fresh strawberries (nice and fresh), and salted caramel chocolate torte, topped with chocolate ice. Ream and cashews with black sesame seeds. All tjree were amazing!

Prompt, friendly service, delicious food, wonderful experience! Highly recommended!

text:
I've come here a few times and this is my official fav place in Chinatown for bubble tea.  It has more of a clean tea taste compared to Kung Fu or Vivi.  I like the jasmine milk tea.  You can tailor the ice and sweetness to your preference.  The black sesame is good too but I recommend less sweet.  Bubbles are included.

They also serve some snacks that are reasonably priced.  Jenga is also around so groups can distract themselves.  The only negative about this place is no loyalty card and sometimes the lines are a bit outta control and disorderly.
name: Tea Do
categories: Juice Bars & Smoothies, Bubble Tea, Food, Coffee & Tea

text:
I'm not much of a sweet tooth, but these popsicles are just the right amount of sweet. They have a variety of flavors that rotate I believe. I've only been here twice and saw different flavors both times. The first time I went, I got the sweet corn pop and it was THE BEST. My girlfriend wanted to trade her lychee pop for my corn, so I shared most of mine.

The second time we went, I was hoping to see the sweet corn, but :(

The black sesame pop was decent, I just had sesame seeds in between my teeth for the next hour. These pops are a refreshing dessert after a nice meal at the nearby restaurants.
name: Lil' Pop Shop
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts

text: Outstanding food, good drinks, and some of the best ice cream in Tucson! Favorite flavors include black sesame and bourbon almond brittle. I have gone here with smaller groups with no reservations, a big group with a reservation, and just for ice cream and service has been good but not great (hence 4 not 5 stars). It is a little chaotic with the large numbers of customers and staff navigating a small space, but tables are spacious. You can come in and just order ice cream and sit at open tables and staff gives water and napkins, very classy. Glad to see improvements in downtown!
name: HUB Restaurant & Ice Creamery

text:
Love this place - in part because mango is my favorite fruit and I would happily eat fresh mango every day. I even love eating around the pit and getting the fibers all stuck in my teeth. 

So a whole dessert shop centered around the magnificent mango? Yes please. 

- Mango juice with mango chunks and lychee jelly. Perfect for a blistering summer day. (And every day.)

- Snow white juice with green tea ice cream, red bean, and rice balls. Is there a more Asian dessert? Possibly not. Really nice blend of textures - my favorites were the chewy rice balls. By the way, each of these desserts is around $8-9 so by no means cheap but they do fill up the plates to heaping. 

- Also ordered the hot black sesame paste soup with peanut mochi. Brought me immediately back to childhood. Mango mango's version is probably a little less "authentic" than other places in Chinatown - it's a lot thicker and sweeter, which is to say, exactly how I like it. I think "chun" sesame paste soup is runnier and more bitter, with more of the sesame flavor, but I absolutely loved this. 

Plenty of seating with both upstairs and downstairs tables. The waiters were all really friendly. Just wished they could use less plastic everything.
name: Mango Mango Dessert

text:
Visited: July 7 2019

My companions and I stumbled upon TSUJIRI and we decided to make a pit stop for some matcha goodness.

There were street parking but they were all taken and metered so we decided to park across the street at Save On Foods (we shopped there first to make our parking legit).

The inside of the restaurant was very zen; peaceful and serene.  (It was a Sunday afternoon but the shop wasn't busy)  Since it was a rainy day,  I quickly decided on a hot beverage.  I ordered the black sesame matcha latte and it was indeed satisfying.  Not a whole lot of black sesame taste but the matcha was intense.  At first glance, I thought the drink was well worth the price of admission (almost $7) as it came in a large tumbler.  Upon closer look, the tumbler was double walled (presumably to keep drinks hot longer) so the drink wasn't as large it seems to be.
name: TSUJIRI Japanese Tea House

text: This place was really delicious! I had the mushroom burger and it's a portabello stuffed with cheese put on a bun with lettuce and tomato and it was very good. The cheese fries were hot with a delicious blend of cheese on them and the black sesame mil shake was delicious. Others in my party got burgers and said the burgers were very good. The restaurant was clean and comfortable. A little cold but it was a hot day! Shake shack is the best new place I've tried in quiet a while and I'm so glad I did.

text:
I am so happy I discovered this little frozen yogurt joint! It's located inside the same building as Tyger Tyger, and although I've never tried the food I think I might now! 

I got the ube flavored frozen yogurt with fruity pebbles. It was really yummy and not too sweet. This frozen yogurt seems to be better quality than other chain frozen yogurts, so the higher price makes sense. They had other flavors including thai tea and black sesame. 

Super nice staff and lovely aesthetic inside.
name: Monkeyshine
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food

text:
This place is located in the Funk Zone, which is a quaint little open market style place that hosts a few other establishments. The interior is very trendy with a bunch of aesthetic decorations, including the famous pink lanterns that line the ceiling and help cultivate the super cute vibe inside.

Opted for ice cream in a taiyaki fish cone. Keep in mind that these cones are significantly smaller than the ones that are often seen in popular chains throughout LA/socal. Couldn't tell if the worker who was swirling my ice cream was being stingy but my ice cream came out looking very sad and lopsided. Paid an additional 50 cents for fruity pebbles on top. In photo attached you can see that my hand is way bigger than the cone itself and that the serving of ice cream is quite small as well. Overall the presentation was quite disappointing and looked very different from the photos advertised online. 

In terms of the actual taste..
Taiyaki fish cones: I saw that there were multiple already premade and on display, you could tell that it wasn't fresh and had been sitting out for a while. The best part of taiyaki cones is the contrasting crunchy exterior to the soft inside breading after it is first made, it could have been a lot better if their cones were made-to-order. The bread was, as expected, hard from having been set out for a while and also was quite bland, there was nothing memorable about it. 

Ice cream: They had four flavors available, chocolate, vanilla, black sesame, and mango sticky rice. Opted for the latter two in hopes of finally having some type of Asian-inspired dessert in this city which has very mediocre Asian cuisine overall. First of all, the cone was so small that there was very little ice cream that came with it. Black sesame did not have that mellow nutty flavor and strangely tasted more sour and lemon-y. The mango sticky rice did not taste even remotely of mango and had a very potent aftertaste that I could not get off my tongue. To be honest I didn't want to be too critical given that it is probably impossible to measure up to actual Asian ice cream shops back in the bay or LA but it's hard to describe what exactly they tasted like - I just know for sure that they did NOT taste anything like what I was expecting. 

For a place to specifically pride itself in serving Asian ingredients and spices in their ice cream, this place was really far off the mark. I really wanted to like it but both flavors were extremely disappointing - neither of them tasted anything like what they were labeled and I honestly have to question if it is because the establishment is run by people who do not have an in-depth understanding of Asian flavors. Disappointed, but I shouldn't be surprised given that this is Santa Barbara. Considering the price point for what you get, including paying an additional 50 cents for each topping, I have to give this place a solid no. Overall, I encourage you all to save your money or spend a little more and go to McConnell's instead for some actual high quality ice cream.
name: Monkeyshine
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food

text: Excellent service. The soft had a wonderful texture but not a lot of flavor, unfortunately. I tried black sesame and it did nothing for me. I got coconut and it just tasted like cream with a mild essence of coconut. I appreciate it wasn't super sweet, though. My wife got a berry basil popsicle, there was no vegan soft serve option. It was very flavorful but too tart. She couldn't finish it. Ambience is the best. Really cool with the pink lights.
name: Monkeyshine
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food

text:
Finally! Mochi donuts in STL Thank you Pokedoke for bringing these amazing chewy donuts to us

Mochi donuts were originated from from Japan and is one of the star product at Mister Donut in Taiwan. It was super popular since about at least 10 years ago in Taiwan. I never seen these being sold here in the US until recent years. It's becoming a new hit in cities with more Asian populations. I am so super excited that we can finally get them here in St. Louis! 

If you never tried, they are a hybrid of cake donuts and mochi, with a dense and chewy texture. Usually a sugar/flavored glazed will be applied on one side of it. This week, they have Strawberry and Black Sesame and I love them both!!! Not quite as chewy as I would hope but it definitely meets my standard and every bite is so joyful

They have had Matcha, Taro, Cookies and Cream and powdered sugar flavors before. I think only the Delmar and Kirkwood locations have it right now. And they said you can contacted them with few days notice to customize the flavor you like for your event! I will definitely try to get all the flavors in the future
name: PokeDoke
categories: Food, Poke, Bubble Tea, Korean, Restaurants

text:
Monkeyshine has finally opened! A cute little ice cream place that shares a sliver of the new hot spot restaurant Tyger Tyger located in the Funk Zone. 

I came here with my son to check it out and we were kindly greeted by the two employees working. Sorry didn't get their names but they were both helpful and offered us samples to try of their unique soft serve ice cream flavors. Toasted rice, Thai chili chocolate, black sesame, and ginger. The toasted rice was the winner so we chose that flavor. 

I wanted to try the cool looking fish cone despite them looking dry, burnt, and not too pretty but I was very surprised at how yummy they were! It's comparable to a waffle cone with a hint of cinnamon flavor. Definitely recommend trying it! 

Like most of the new hot spots popping up around town the prices aren't cheap! After ordering two fish cones, and five toppings later the price came out to $14. Not cheap by any means but it was still a nice treat and fun to try! 

Overall a cute little place to check out with the best exterior in the Funk Zone! Love the pretty pink lanterns outside.
name: Monkeyshine
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food

text:
Matcha Black Sesame Latte ($6.75+tax) tasted more like black sesame with milk. There was a hint of matcha flavour though. Edmonton was getting cold, so this warm drink was gooooodd!! However, I think I would prefer just the Matcha Latte drinks instead.

Matcha Rare Cheesecake ($5.75+tax) was creamy and had strong matcha flavour! Super delicious! Lovedddd it! My fave dessert!

Yuzu Tart ($5.25+tax) was nommy as well! Personally, I don't really like sour desserts, but this was actually pretty good! Normally, the yuzu flavour desserts don't have much of the "yuzu" taste, but this tart had quite a strong yuzu flavour! Not bad!

Overall, I love anything that has matcha in it! I can't wait for Vancouver location to open. Is it still "opening soon"? What's taking them so long to open in Vancouver? I feel like it's been 6 yrs since they announced it..... Highly recommend this place for the matcha lovers.
name: TSUJIRI Japanese Tea House

text:
Monkeyshine is located in the Funk Zone in the same building as Tyger Tyger and Dart Coffee! This cute new little ice cream place is delicious.

They have a few different flavors that you can choose from. They have a toasted rice, thai chili chocolate, black sesame, and a ginger flavor. They were all really good! I ended up going with the toasted rice flavor which was my favorite. I got it with one of their fish cones which was also super tasty and it tasted just like a waffle cone. 

They also have tons of toppings to choose from as well. I didn't end up getting any this time but I plan to in the future. They even have vegan options here too! I'm not vegan but my friend is so I'll be sure to tell her!

Overall the atmosphere of this place, the ice cream, and the cone make me want to come back here soon! Thanks for the awesome first experience Monkeyshine, I'll be back soon to try your toppings!
name: Monkeyshine
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food

text:
I love coming here for desserts and drinks! It's one of the regular places that I frequent. There aren't many places that offer traditional japanese desserts and authentic matcha drinks and desserts. 

One of my favorite things is the parfaits! There are couple varieties. My favorite has a few layers of the mix soft serve, toasted rice, sweet azuki bean (red bean) paste + mochi balls. Mmm so good!

My go to drink is the Black Sesame Matcha latte. Such a great combo! They have soy milk for their lattes if you are lactose intolerant. 

The staff are very friendly and always helpful to explain anything from the menu.

If you are new to matcha and want their soft serve, start with the vanilla/matcha mix, all matcha may be too strong to start with off the bat. 

They have a cute little tatami room for bigger groups where you need to take off your shoes to sit inside.

Earlier this year, they opened their patio so you can enjoy the sun!
name: TSUJIRI Japanese Tea House

text:
Cute little poke spot on Passyunk. The staff was super friendly even though she was the only one working and there was a line of people waiting to be served, her energy was  great. She even offered me samples of her 3 special sauce - black sesame was my favorite. 

I customized my own poke  bowl and she was really generous with the serving size. I even got a free sirarcha sauce because we spent over $20. The bowl was delicious, however, mid way through my meal, my stomach was not feeling the greatest. My boyfriend also felt the same. It's most likely the salmon and tuna that was not very fresh. 

Love the service  but I'm not sure if I will be returning just based off of my experience.
name: Big Catch Poke
categories: Seafood, Restaurants, Poke, Japanese, Food, Juice Bars & Smoothies, Bubble Tea

text:
I contacted Bellefonte Cafe through their facebook, last week, looking to make reservations for my birthday. Dave, whom I think might be the owner, responded promptly. For my first visit, it was just a friend and I. This restaurant seems to have once been a home and has since be converted. So, be mindful when parking, it's street parking and there are houses nearby. 

There is a painted sign out front and there is a sphere water fountain in front of the stairs. When stepping onto the porch there are two entrances; a door to your left and a door if you keep walking straight. I think it is seat yourself, because I've never seen anyone waiting at the door to seat people and I've seen other customers just walk in and seat themselves. Both times I've made reservations they have a little paper placeholder with your name and reservation time on it. I like that they use both sides of it; they seem environmentally conscious. They don't automatically put straws (or lemons) in your complimentary glass of water and their take-out containers are recyclable, if not biodegradable. I would describe Bellefonte Cafe's style as eclectic. I like that none of the tables, chairs match, and it is boldy colored with complementary artwork.

My 1st visit: As we were sitting down, I told the waiter I was communicating with someone running their facebook and asked to speak with them. Dave, the owner (I think), came over to our table to introduce himself. I like face-to-face communication after corresponding online in a situation like that; good owners care about their customers. He was nice to give me a complimentary dessert for my birthday. 

The waiter seemed to be, I don't know if distracted was the word to describe it, but something was off. One thing I wasn't a fan of was that he never came to ask how things were. They weren't that busy either so I don't know if there was something happening behind the scenes.  He was prompt with refilling our water glasses though. 

I ordered their Thai Chicken Salad (slided chicken breast, orange lime ginger sauce, black sesame seeds, scallions, seasonal greens, grape tomato, cucumber.) The greens and other veggies were super fresh. But the chicken was dry and the sauce was overpoweringly tangy. Also, I didn't taste any ginger. I think maybe that would have balanced out the sauce a little more.

My 2nd visit today was much better. Our waiter was a curly haired bearded guy named Dave. My mom and I weren't really interested in any of their apps so we shared an order of their Hummus Stuffed Avocado (half avocado stuffed with homemade hummus, topped with grape tomato, red onion, Kalamata olives, extra virgin olive oil, chopped herbs, served with crostinis.) It was really good. Their hummus was delicious! Also, the Kalamata olives were the best I've ever had. The ingredients go really well together, and I think it's perfect portion for two.

For my entree I ordered their Pine Nut Salad (roasted pine nuts, blue cheese, scallions, seasonal greens, grape tomatoes, cucumber, honey mustard vinaigrette) with chicken for an extra $2. Again, their veggies were very fresh. Their tomatoes and cucumber were my favorites. I asked for my dressing on the side. Dave dropped off our food and a waitress came over with the dressing a couple secs later. I tasted it and my mom tasted it and it tasted like regular vinaigrette. When we saw Dave, I asked about the honey mustard vinaigrette that was supposed to be with the salad. He went and got it but I don't know if there was confusion happening or what, but he said it was the same one that the waitress brought. But the one he brought, you could taste the honey mustard, with the other one, you could taste the vinegar. Regardless, they were both yummy. I just wanted to make sure I tasted both of them.

Also, they seem to have a musician every night around like 6:30ish. It's a fun atmosphere with good food. I'm sure I will be back and am looking forward to trying other things. The town of Bellefonte has it's own local flavor (they also have arts festival too). Check them out.
name: Bellefonte Cafe

text:
I had dinner at Double Knot last night with a group of 6 and it was spectacular! I had heard good things about this restaurant, but it exceeded my expectations.  We got the chef's tasting menu for 5 people and thoroughly enjoyed it. There are two options: pick your own dishes (roughly one from each section of the menu) or just let the chef choose. We did the former - pick our own - but the waitress helped guide us towards some of her favorite and/or most popular dishes. After that delicious dish after delicious dish came out as they were ready. (The 6th guest was gluten free and the waitress helped her select allergy-friendly items separately that she said she enjoyed).

We ended up with:
Yellowtail sashimi - everyone loved this - the flavors were great and fish so tender
Tuna with avocado - also a big hit and great quality fish and sauce very tasty
Japanese fried chicken - I think the restaurant is known for this - it was very good
Edamame dumpling - also one of the most popular dishes. Some thought this was a standout, others thought good, but not as thrilled
Salmon sushi roll - great quality, but less exciting than some other dishes
Octopus robatayaki - deliciously tender and well-seasoned
Rib-eye robatayaki - this was absolutely fantastic. You wouldn't think you could make a piece of rib-eye on a stick that much of a standout, but this dish melted in my mouth
Beef short rib - good sauce and flavor, but the robatayaki was better
Broiled sea bass - delicious, melts in your mouth - definitely a favorite
Crispy brussel sprouts - also got high marks from the table
Dessert: black sesame "cheesecake" tart - everyone seemed to like it and it had nice flavor, but the savory items definitely outshined the dessert

Overall, I think we all agreed there wasn't a bad dish. They were all great, with some standing out more than others, but really exceptional start to finish. We were also all impressed with the portion size.  For $55 they really give you your money's worth and portion out the items well.  We ended up taking home a few leftovers because we simply couldn't eat it all and were very full by the end.  Though, at the same time everyone did sample everything so it wasn't completely overwhelming. The chef's tasting was nice because everything came out such that we could split it equally and you get enough items that you're still feeling like you get to taste a lot of dishes.  I could see ordering a la carte being fun too, though, if everyone picks a few dishes they are excited about - not sure how it would price out if you did it that way. The cocktail menu also has a number of exciting options and we all enjoyed sampling with some advice from the waitress. 

The ambience of the restaurant is also very cool.  The top floor is more of a bar/lounge area, whereas the downstairs (where we ate) is setup like a speakeasy with a separate unmarked door and very cool vibe. We were also seated at probably the best table in the restaurant, a plush circle booth that is a few steps up from the main dining floor and overlooks the whole restaurant. It was more private and special (and comfortable) for our group, but we still got to enjoy the ambience of the downstairs restaurant.  Just lucked into this table, but would definitely request if possible in the future with an appropriate size group. Though the other tables I'm sure are fine and the food is the worth sitting at any table.

I will definitely be back to Double Knot!
name: Double Knot

text:
I had their tasting menu ($60) with 10 selections + mochi. I let the chef choose my dishes, and here's what I got:


From specialty sashimi, the salmon with spicy ponzu and soy ginger. The salmon was nice, but the ponzu completely overpowered the fish.


From cold, the ceviche with kampachi, mango, and yuzu kosho ponzu. Also not my favorite, something about the flavors didn't sit right with me. It was pretty zingy.


From sushi/sashimi, the toro nigiri. It was really good toro and melted in my mouth.


From crispy, the shrimp taco with radish, chili, and avocado. The shrimp could've been crispier, but I really liked the creamy avocado at the bottom, and the flavors all balanced nicely.


From small, the edamame dumplings. This dish was my favorite of the evening. Edamame dumplings don't sound like much but these were creamy and delicious, and the accompanying broth tasted a lot like shiitake mushrooms.


From the robatayaki, the octopus and the rib eye scallion. The octopus was a bit overcooked and had too much sauce. The rib eye scallion was juicy, but I felt like the scallions could have had so much more flavor. I'm not sure how they managed to make scallions so tasteless, but they succeeded.


From the fish, the broiled seabass with truffle soy and pea shoots. I was pleasantly surprised by this dish, since the fish was very flaky but fatty enough to maintain its juiciness. My only complaint was that it was on the salty side.


From the sides, the black cod fried rice with miso caramel. The rice itself was prepared well, but I'm not a huge fan of sweeter dishes. Miso has a great depth of flavor, and I felt like this dish was missing some of that.


For ice cream mochi I got orange creamsicle, Belgian chocolate, and vanilla chocolate chip. They weren't anything special, and at this point I just sat there thinking really? After giving me all the least adventurous dishes you could've picked, these are the flavors you give me. I was expecting flavors much more interesting than this (like black sesame perhaps?).


That was all I got. At this point, you might be thinking, but wait. You said there were 10 selections + mochi, I only see 9 selections + mochi. Where in the world is the tenth dish? Trust me, I was wondering the same thing. Apparently because I was a solo diner, I only got 9 selections. This fact was not made apparent to me at the start of my meal, and as a result, I was pretty annoyed when I found out I would only get 9 dishes at the same price of 10. In case any of you decide to go solo at the restaurant, just keep this in mind.


All in all, this meal was incredibly ordinary. None of the dishes besides the edamame dumplings stood out to me. The chef's choices of dishes were also really boring. If you're looking for something more adventurous, I would recommend choosing your own meal.
name: Double Knot

text:
I came here to grab some dessert after a dinner of hand drawn noodles. There is no better way to end off the day! 

Having never had shaved ice cream or rolled ice cream before, I didn't know what to expect. We ordered the pink cosmos and matcha rolled icecream with unlimited toppings (given the small size of the cup, there really is a limit to the number of toppings you can put on. I keep imagining myself dousing the rolls with mountains of mochi and fruit pieces, but the workers are much more conservative with their serving sizes). 

BTW.. the pink spoons turn blue/purple when exposed to cold! That was really neat. 

[Food] 
I was really looking forward to seeing them shave a huge block of ice in persion, but a cup of pink appeared out of nowhere. I decided that they may have already pre-shaved and then had it in the freezer for convenience.  The texture was heavenly.. melt off the tongue... very cotton candy like. However, there was something very artificial tasting, almost medicinal, about the pink cosmos. I could not decide whether it was the ice cream base or the syrup. I would probably try the cheesecake or black sesame flavor next time

The person who made our rolled icecream was quite skilled. He produced 5 perfect rolls which were coated with our choice of toppings.The matcha rolled icecream stole the show with it's very heavy and distinctive flavor. There was a little bitterness to balance the sweetness, making the dessert quite delectable. The mochi and red beans were the perfect toppings. Unfortunately, the spoons were not quite strong enough to break through the rolls  - you definitely needed to work at it. That being said, the presentation, performance, and taste was worth 5 stars. 

We unfortunately ate all of the icecream before any photos were taken.
name: Ice Land
categories: Food, Bubble Tea, Shaved Ice, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts

text: Best coffee shop in Philly, hands down. Inventive lattes (cardamom rose!) to activated charcoal bagels, it's a really unique place. Great customer service. I would recommend the vegan lox with cream cheese on a black sesame bagel. AMAZING.
name: The Kettle Black
categories: Bagels, Food, Bakeries, Coffee & Tea

text:
This was by far our favorite restaurant of the trip.  I know when you think of New Orleans, you immediately think of Israeli food - NOT - but I guess we just like what we like.

There were six of us and we made our lunch reservation a little over a week in advance.  However, it was already slim pickings for time slots since we were visiting over a very popular weekend.  Luckily, you have the option to try for outdoor seating the day of.  You can call Shaya at 10am when they first open to make a same-day patio reservation, but we instead just showed up at the restaurant when we wanted to eat and were very lucky they had a patio table available for 6 immediately.

Aside from being able to eat our lunch at a normal hour, eating outside was even more of a blessing because the A/C inside the restaurant was FREEZING.  While I am sure that wood-burning oven makes the staff toasty warm, I am just as sure the indoor guests were most uncomfortable.  Other reviews even mentioned teeth chattering!

Once we were seated in the lovely and comfortable patio area, our epic meal began.  The service was quick and friendly.  The drinks were tasty.  The food was amazing.  The portions are pretty small, as you might expect, so order a bunch of things to share, and maybe some duplicate dishes too to make sure there is enough for everyone.  I wouldn't come here planning to stick to a modest budget.  This is the perfect restaurant to go nuts and end a nice vacation with a bang.

They brought out only one or two fluffy pitas at a time for our table of six to share.  We tore into each pita like animals, scalding our hands in the process every. single. time.  Meanwhile, the table beside us used a fork and knife to cut up their pita, like civilized people.  

I'm pretty sure we enjoyed our meal more.

Normally when a restaurant offers me a dessert menu I take a hard pass.  In this case, I *demanded* to see the dessert menu and, though we had eaten plenty already, ordered three dessert items.

There you have it.  I will compile a list of what we ordered below.  Everything was good.  If I were to skip something, it might be the labneh - but even that was good.  If you are a fan of Mediterranean food, you can't go wrong here.

Salatim:
Lutenitsa (x2)
Bulgarian purée of roasted pepper, eggplant, garlic and tomato

Tabouleh
parsley and bulgar wheat salad, red onion, toasted almonds, preserved lemon

Labneh
Progress Farm's yogurt, wax peppers, radishes

Wood Roasted Brussel Sprouts
black harissa, tahini, pickled onions

Some kind of delicious seasoned olive oil also came with the pita for dipping.

Hummus:
Curried Cauliflower
caramelized onions and cilantro

Lamb Ragú
with crispy chickpeas

Small Plates:
Falafel
cabbage salad and cucumber tzatziki (the cabbage salad had some kind of floral vinaigrette - I think orange blossom - that we were captivated by)

Crispy Halloumi
strawberries, mint, pistachio

Salad:
Baby Kale
golden beets, black garlic-verjus vinaigrette, pumpkin seeds, satsumas

Israeli Salad
cherry tomatoes, cucumbers, parsley, za'atar and Bulgarian feta

Some sort of pomegranate/lemon soda... there might have been other stuff in it I don't remember, but most importantly, it was tasty.

Some kind of white wine.

THEY WERE OUT OF COFFEE  :-O

Desserts:
Malabi
vanilla bean custard, pomegranate, kumquat, coconut, black sesame

Orange Blossom Kanafeh
crispy filo, sweet cream, passionfruit, pistachio

Milk and Honey
cheesecake, mixed nut granola, burnt honey gelato

text:
Finally they open!!! Have been waiting this for couple months. I think they supposed to open on July, but they open on August 1st. 
The first day I got Matcha Chocolate Truffles & Angus Short Ribs. Both of them so delicious!!
If they put matcha ice cream it will great!!! I like the crepes, not too sweet, and enough crisps for me. 
And the Angus Beef is yummy!!! 
And I also got Black Sesame Shake. For me, I don't really like it. I feel like it bit bitter. I don't know maybe I just eat the crepes or the shake is not sweet at all.

And the second day I got Chocolate Nut Party. It so chocolate! Not too much sweet but too much chocolate for me. If you are chocolate lover you should try this! And I got Dark Chocolate Shake. And it still so chocolate so thick!
 
The line was so crazy! But not too long to wait. When I came it was number 50 something and mine was 67. Then I got my crepes 30 minutes later. Not bad, some bubble tea store longer than that and that's only drink. But this is freshly made. They make the skin after you order it then put all the toppings. 

Very recommended! First in Philadelphia (I think) Japanese Crepes!
name: T-Swirl Crêpe

text:
I visited Bubble House on a whim, during a quick two-day trip to Philly. I happened to read a mention of the joint online the day I was there, and I am a fan of bubble tea so I couldn't resist. It must be said, though, that I am no bubble tea afficionado. It has been awhile since I have had anything but the super sugary, frozen bubble teas at a local chain, which I still enjoy.

We arrived at Bubble House with the kind of appetite where anything you stuff in your mouth is going to taste gourmet. Additionally, we were on vacation and in love, so maybe my review is biased, but I loved the place.

The wife and I split a veggie hoagie and salad, which were both great but not especially memorable. I have a real fondness for spicy potatoes, and predictably loved the wasabi mashed potatoes. The sweet potato fries and the orange ginger dipping sauce were the real winners, though. If I lived nearby, I could see myself swinging by for bubble tea and fries pretty regularly.

The bubble tea was so good we ordered a gigantic, Big Gulp sized one to go after each enjoying the ones we got during our meal. Probably my favorite was one I'd never order: black sesame. Good thing I have my better half around to order the right thing. I wish I had bubble tea like this in my town; you can actually taste the tea while still feeling like you got dessert in a cup.
name: The Bubble House
categories: American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Tea Rooms, Coffee & Tea, Food, Asian Fusion, Restaurants

text: Tried the lychee and strawberry one and it was super delicious. I really like how the crepes here are a little crunchy around the edges - I was afraid they would be soft and soggy but these had a great texture. This place has a credit card minimum though so we also ended up having to get a blended black sesame smoothie to reach it.
name: T-Swirl Crêpe

text:
Absolutely LOVED double Knot!

Our Japanese grill favorites in order: 
1) Kobe beef
2) chicken breast
3) short rib
4) lobster - which was still amazing!

Other loves:
-king salmon sashimi
-yellowtail scallion roll-so simple yet so good!
-duck "scrapple" bao which was more confit than scrapple
-black sesame mochi ice cream! The perfect ending to an amazing dinner 

Likes:
Bacon yakisoba

Did NOT like the Tofu-it was heavily fried and mostly consisted of breading! Avoid!

The service was friendly and we will be back soon!
name: Double Knot

text:
I'm amazed at just how disappointed I am by today's lunch. Why don't I just toss it up as rubbish and move on with my day? Mainly because I only had $10 in cash at the NoLibs 2nd Street Fair to spend on food and $6 of that $10 was, basically, wasted leaving me feeling unsatisfied.

I thought that the Dan Dan Noodles sounded really good because I adore those noodles at Han Dynasty. Well, not all Dan Dan Noodles are created equal. DumpnRoll's version was made with Raman Noodles (the packaged kind you get for 50 cents with the flavor packet- and they could have benefited, greatly from the flavor packet). Do you know those tiny, foil packets are like silver dollars in jail? Learned that from OITNB. Anyway, the Raman were topped with shredded carrot, mini cucumber batons, slivered scallions, black sesame seeds and served with a small container of mildly spicy peanut sauce. I asked for hot sauce, but they did not have any which dumbfounded me as Asian food is always offered with Sriracha or chili oil.

The Raman Noodles were cooked to, almost, mush. The veggies atop were fresh & crisp. The sauce, although it offered some heat, was extraordinarily bland and not quite enough for all the noodles. I thought that the amount of sauce was the cause of its tastelessness, so I returned to the truck, now ravenous, and requested another container of sauce which I enthusiastically emptied onto the noodles.

I was so voracious, I ate half of them, flavorless, in all their squishy splendor. Now here I am with a belly fully of Raman and $4..
name: Dump-N-Roll

text:
Wow -- so delicious. I loved that there are so many options and each dish is small, so you can try a lot!

The only downside is that the waiters were almost too attentive, taking away our dishes nearly seconds after we finished. Additionally, I felt like most of our dishes were on the sweeter side. A bit more salt would be preferred.

For more details on why I loved my meal...

Small hot dishes:
-short rib: really delicious flavor. Super tender!
-rib eye with scallions: similar flavor to the short rib. Also very good, but I preferred the short rib as I thought it was more flavorful.
-tuna with rice cracker: the cracker (basically a block of rice with a fried outside) was a bit tough. Overall liked it, but wouldn't recommend ordering it.
-pastrami bao bun: super unique dish. I love pastrami and thought the meat and slaw had good flavor, but there was way too much mustard on my piece. Would give this a try if you're looking for a fun, tasty bite.
-fried chicken with onions: hearty serving for $7. Not the best chicken I've had, but a good filler if you're not looking to completely blow your bank account.

Main:
-sea bass with pea shoots: Pretty decent hunk of fish. Had a great bright and crispy outside, and a nice sweet sauce on the plate. Our dish was a little cold, though. And I wish it was saltier. 
-black cod fried rice: ***this was probably my favorite dish! There were so many different elements to the rice which made it really delicious -- the saltiness of the cod (although honestly I would have preferred just a pinch of salt in the dish itself), sweetness of the caramel, spiciness of the peppers, and the pop of the edamame. 

Dessert:
-black sesame mocha: I like sesame so I enjoyed this dessert. Nothing super special, though.
-strawberry shortcake with sesame: would highly recommend this. Was a pretty big dessert so would be good for sharing. So delicious!
name: Double Knot

text: I've been wanting to try out The Kettle Black for a while and finally got to try it! I got there at around 1pm on a Saturday and only the Everything bagel and 2 pastries were left. I was so sad because I wanted to try the Black Sesame bagel! I ended up getting the Everything bagel (toasted) with cream cheese, onions and tomato. It was warm, chewy and delicious! I also got a latte and it was also delicious. To have more bagel and pastry options, would suggest getting there at least before 11am.. it seemed like a lot of the pastries had sold out even by noon that day. If you are driving, there are 2 hour street parking spots around. (Note: Right around the corner of The Kettle Black, do NOT turn onto Green Street and then N Hancock Street looking for parking.. N Hancock Street is super super narrow and I was scared that I was going to damage my car while driving through that street!) I can't wait to go back (earlier during the day) to try the Black Sesame bagel and to get another latte! If I lived right around there, I would definitely pop in often.
name: The Kettle Black
categories: Bagels, Food, Bakeries, Coffee & Tea

text:
Doth my eyes deceive me? Is there an honest to goodness boulangerie in my neighborhood? Can it be true? Is there an adorable little place where I can get the most delightful, airy pastries and breads a plenty? 

There is indeed! Oh joy! Oh adoration. There is nothing that makes me happier than a business that opens and fills a desperate neighborhood need. Thank you Kettle Black.

Come early for the first bake and snag yourself a baguette or two. Perfection. Black sesame bagels are a revelation. If you're feeling fancy, get some trimmings on it. Coffee on point and lastly, three words for you: Pain au chocolat. Perfect amount of flakiness with each buttery bite and a perfect chocolate ratio. Have mercy!

P.S. kitchen closes at 2 pm but stays open until closing or until they sell out!
name: The Kettle Black
categories: Bagels, Food, Bakeries, Coffee & Tea

text:
Philly is home to quite a few steakhouses. You've got Barclay Prime and Butcher and Singer from Stephen Starr. The chains also have you set with Ruth's Chris and Smith & Wollensky, of which the latter is one of my favorites in NYC. And of course, you've also got Del Frisco's, a "chain" steakhouse that embodies all things power lunch or expense accounts. And regular readers know that, at least in my opinion, higher-end chains like Ruth's Chris and Del Frisco's are nothing to scoff at. If anything they have consistent execution and service down pat.

Philly's outpost for Del Frisco's is cavernous. It all starts with the iron-clad gates that welcome you in. You can venture downstairs and have your meal in a bank vault. 

Or enter straight ahead and enjoy a drink at the bar, with the vaulted ceilings providing a grand atmosphere. 

Or do as the GF and I did and reserve a table upstairs to overlook it all, right next to a spiral staircase filled with hundreds, if not thousands of bottles of wine.

Old Fashioned [$14]
Knob Creek bourbon, muddled cherry, orange, sugar, bitters

I started the meal with an oft-enjoyed cocktail. Can't go wrong with Knob Creek - the orange helped to add some lightness to this well-made drink.

Diet Coke [$4]

The GF wasn't feeling a drink that night, so went with a Diet Coke. FYI - this is the type of place that won't invest in fountain soda, for reasons that are financially obvious. Interestingly though, the soda was initially completely flat. No carbonation whatsoever. The server was a bit flummoxed as well, but once we offered her a taste to dispel any disbelief (which she declined), she brought us another which was just fine. Weird.

Bread Service

The meal starts off with bread service - crusty, yeasty, and salty sesame bread. Whipped butter was served at room temp, which is always appreciated. The server stopped by to ask if we wanted some more bread, but we decided to save room for what was to come.

Del's Salad [$10]

The GF ordered the house salad, which the servers graciously split for us, much to the chagrin of the GF. A thick-cut, crispy piece of bacon sat atop Romaine and field greens, in addition to a melange of cherry tomatoes, carrots, avocado, green onions, and croutons. Ranch dressing was provided as well.

Fried Calamari [$17]
Shanghai style 

This was our second time at Del Frisco's in Philly and we had to order the calamari again. Sweet and crispy, the calamari had a nice bit of head on the end. The mung bean sprouts and pickled jalapeno offered some texture and tang, with the sweetness of the black sesame accenting the delicious sauce. Highly recommended.

8 oz. Filet Mignon [$39]

The GF went with the 8 ounce filet, cooked nicely medium-rare. This is USDA prime beef, though not aged. It had great flavor with a tenderness that's prototypical of the filet. The crust was nicely seasoned and accentuated the beef. Unfortunately, here, they cut into the steak before bringing it to your table. Understandably, they want to get the temperature correct before their patrons dig in, but in my mind, it brings down the experience a bit, especially at these prices.

16 oz. Ribeye [$45]

As expected, I went with the ribeye which was beautifully seasoned on the outside. This USDA prime beef is wet-aged for 16 to 18 days. While I give the nod to Ruth's Chris's ribeye for their superlative crust, this was still quite delicious. The deckle or cap of the steak was gorgeously marbled - clearly my favorite cut on the steak.

Onion Rings [$10]

Knowing the belly of this pig, you'd expect me to order a few sides as well. For me, a steakhouse's sides are often measured by their onions rings. Though not as crispy as other steakhouses, these were huge and had a creamy batter - reminiscent of a malt/vinegar fish n chips batter.

Lobster Mac n Cheese [$18]

When I see lobster mac n cheese on the menu, it will be ordered. This was creamy and the briny essence of the lobster comes through nicely, with a few chunks of lobster interspersed throughout. The top of the mac n cheese was nicely crispy, offering some texture to each bite. 

And with that, our meal was over, with plenty of leftovers for the next day. Other than the flat soda ($4!!), the meal was on point and service was excellent. Though Barclay Prime and Ruth's Chris remain my favorites in Philly, Del Frisco's offers a great meal as well. Not that Kanye West and Kim Kardashian's choices for fine dining are anything to consider (they're not), but they did enjoy a meal here when they were last in town.

And about a week later, we received a thank you card from Del Frisco's. Certainly a nice touch and definitely appreciated!
name: Del Frisco's Double Eagle Steakhouse

text: I have been searching for a good bagel place near old city who doesn't skimp on their everything seasoning. These bagels are well seasoned and are beautifully baked - soft on the inside with a slight crisp on the outside. We had a black sesame bagel with scallion cream cheese, tomato, and cucumber and a cheddar everything bagel, which were both scrumptious. We also ordered a dozen bagels to take home and freeze. I am excited to make this place part of my weekend ritual.
name: The Kettle Black
categories: Bagels, Food, Bakeries, Coffee & Tea

text: What an amazing experience! The service was on point, and the server was extremely detailed. She recommended ordering 4 dishes (to share) between my friend and I. I ordered lovers knot as my cocktail drink and it was so refreshing. My overall favourite dish was the duck bao. For dessert I got moji - assortment of flavours (I liked coconut and black sesame) 5/5 would recommend, especially if you love asian fusion.

text: Had this place bookmarked since moving to Philly last summer and finally crawled out of bed early this Sunday morning to catch them before they sold out. An early morning stroll, a black sesame bagel with lox and fixings, and an earl grey crème latte made me ~slightly~ consider becoming a morning person. Staff is super friendly, the food and coffee are delicious; would definitely make the trek to buy a loaf of bread (no bread today because of Labor Day weekend) during the weekday; it's that good!
name: The Kettle Black
categories: Bagels, Food, Bakeries, Coffee & Tea

text:
I've been craving a bagel for 3 months to be exact but can never find a place that has vegan cream cheese. After an extensive Yelp research session I found this place and decided to venture out on a Saturday morning. This place opens and closes very early so I suggest coming in early. 

 I've been on this street before since I love getting the vegan pizza right across the street.

I woke up at 9 AM on a Saturday and I was a bit mad about it because I love getting sleep on the weekends. I drove all the way to Fishtown which is about a 20 minute drive. I parked my car kind of far and took a longer than expected walk however it seems like there are many businesses opening in Fishtown because there were so many places I have been meaning to try and they all turned out to be in close proximity to each other.

I walked into Black Kettle and it was packed! I mean I did not expect there to be so many people. I got the black sesame bagel and their seasonal special vegan cream cheese. After taking a bite of this the drive, the walk, the cold weather and having to wake up early did not matter because I was so content with the bagel. I also got the vegan chocolate pastry I think and it was very good. You can honestly taste that it's freshly baked and not frozen and then reheated. I love and support businesses that bake their goodies everyday. It is a lot of man labor and stress so I don't even mind paying more money for that.
name: The Kettle Black
categories: Bagels, Food, Bakeries, Coffee & Tea

text:
Etch exceeded all expectations. We sat at the bar, facing the open kitchen. The wine list is expansive and as said hundreds of times before, the food was incredible. 

We ordered a bottle of the Yangarra Shiraz and it paired well with everything we ate. We had the bread to start (the butters were black sesame garlic and chili mango - trust me, order it!). Then we split the Etch salad - would highly recommend. I would order that for lunch everyday if I lived in town. For entrees, we had the tempura tofu and the special fish, which was corvina on top of brown butter kale farro (kind of like risotto) with roasted carrots, shallots and topped with carrot top pesto. Honestly one of the best fish dishes I have had in months. We ended our meal with the ice cream sundae and the blonde cookie chunks were cooked perfectly. 

What made this experience amazing was the service from our waiter Mathieu S. He was very knowledgeable about the menu and had great recommendations. We were also impressed by his knowledge of the wine menu and suggestions on pairing. 

Any one of these factors would have brought us back, but the combination of thoughtful food, nice ambience, and superb service will have us highly recommending Etch to any and all visiting Nashville.
name: Etch

text: Stopped by this little store in the morning during the weekday. It was around 8am, the store had a  short line already. The cashier was super friendly. We ordered black salt and black sesame with janapeno cream cheese! Omg, the bagels were so good, we really enjoyed them! The coffee was ok, but we were here for the bagel anyway. Only wish the store was a little bigger so people can actually sit down and enjoy the bites. Will definitely come back for more!
name: The Kettle Black
categories: Bagels, Food, Bakeries, Coffee & Tea

text:
Came in on a Tuesday around 6:30PM for a single reservation at the chef'a counter - great option eating solo and watching your food being made. The space overall is big and the chef's counter is quieter than the main bar area.

I opted for the chef's tasting and actually went blind- I let the chef choose and he did not disappoint. You get 10 dishes and a dessert. The notable items I got:
-yellowtail toro sushi: the bite left such a tender citrusy burst, a great start
-kobe beef yakitori: so juicy and tender, seared to perfection - must drizzle the mustard sauce on the side 
-scallop yakitori: my favorite- somehow the chef magically knew I loved scallops? Just slightly charred and each bite was just perfect, miso glaze added a nice touch - if you love seafood, need to put dibs on this! 
- broiled sea bass: served with some garnished veggies and drizzled in miso/teriyaki sauce, the filet was not over cooked and the flavor was just great 
- black sesame ice cream mochi: soft mochi with cold black sesame ice cream filling - the best sweet note and treat to end your night

The deal being $60 pretax was amazing for the amount of food you get (there was more than listed, I just put down the ones I loved). The whole 10 courses took around 1.5 hours at my slow pace though I wished they waited for me to finish each one before the next one came out. I definitely would come back again and maybe see what the chef can surprise me with again! Come with a friend or go alone, great foodie spot.
name: Double Knot

text:
So excited to have such a great bagel place near me!

A little sad there are no breakfast sandwiches but maybe one day they will. I got the black sesame bagel with dill cream cheese and pickled fennel and it was BOMB DOT COM. It wasn't even toasted and I enjoyed it! I can't wait to try out their other goodies but would definitely recommend they get more items on their menu!
name: The Kettle Black
categories: Bagels, Food, Bakeries, Coffee & Tea

text:
I've been walking by this place for a few weeks, and the other day the door opened and I got a whiff of something that smelled amazing. I decided to stop in today on my way to work. 

The interior is super cute with a laid back, relaxed feel. I didn't even realize the place was a bakery, I assumed it was a coffee shop that sold baked goods but not a place that bakes things themselves. 

I ordered a black sesame bagel with butter and a cappuccino. It was really, really good. 

I'm excited to try more of their stuff, but this experience was fantastic.
name: The Kettle Black
categories: Bagels, Food, Bakeries, Coffee & Tea

text: It's hard to go wrong here- drinks, happy hour, sushi, grilled meats- all of it is fantastic. I'm a big fan of Japanese food which is why I prefer it slightly more to Sampan (asian fusion)- nevertheless both are great. The upstairs is definitely more casual/tightly packed-modern lounge vibes- and the downstairs is dimly lit and intimate- my favorite spot to sit is at the sushi bar but there's also cozy seating near the downstairs bar. I've been here several times over the years and love doing the happy hour or chef's tasting for special occasions. The staff is really nice and accommodating of food restrictions and the food always comes out really fast. My favorites are definitely the lover's knot cocktail, big eye tuna roll, edamame dumplings, miso eggplant, black cod fried rice, and the brussels sprouts. Also for dessert the seasonal mochi is really good- it was black sesame one time which I loved. Overall you can spend a good amount of time here and the food is consistently great.
name: Double Knot

text: I don't know why this place has such high ratings. I've tried it twice to give it a fair shot. The first time I got the Black Sesame Cream Milk Tea Boba and it was just... average. I do like the texture and size of the tapioca pearls, but they taste so plain. The black sesame cream was the best part of the drink. I also ordered with 100% sugar and it tasted like 50%. The next time I ordered the brown sugar matcha boba in hopes that the boba would be sweeter, and it was, but it didn't taste that good to me. The matcha was pretty decent though. Definitely not comparable to any LA boba shop. To be honest, Phresh Teas and Mojo's beat Hochaya any day. Maybe I'll go again and try the fruit teas or the pudding tea?
name: Hochaya

text: Really great coffee shop/patisserie/bakery. Wouldn't necessarily call it French. It's a place for bread and coffee - as advertised on the door - but it definitely takes it up a notch in quality and creativity. On one hand, they've perfected the traditional croissant and pain au chocolat. On the other, they offer golden milk, sesame tahini bread, black sesame bagels, and chocolate chip miso sea salt cookies. I'd only ask them to kick up the ambiance and offer a few more cream cheese flavors and they'd be hedging a 5. Voted the bakery in northern liberties Most Worth a Visit. By me. :)
name: The Kettle Black
categories: Bagels, Food, Bakeries, Coffee & Tea

text:
My second visit is pleasant. This time I am sit down have snack at dinner. I believe they are 4.5 stars restaurant not full 5 stars. Although I didn't try their ninja chicken nuggets again, but we do try fried calamari and the the black garlic ramen. They finally have the token ramen with newest ramen dish. Black garlic is one of the kind. It has the black sesame oil with black garlic on it. It is delicious. The calamari was fried very good with good coating. 

The reason they are upgraded is I make a challenge to their boba team. I ask a drink that partial in the menu but not totally in the menu. They have winter Mellon milk tea. I ask if they can do the slush. They said they have not done that before. But they will try. End up it is good drink.

text:
Double Knot is another fantastic concept by the wonderful chef Michael Schulson. Connected to Sampan, the top floor was crowded at the few tables and around the bar on a Friday night. Luckily, we had a reservation, and we were evaded the bustling upstairs and were seated at an table in the intimate basement level. Downstairs, it was equally as crowded, with patrons filling every table, and a very "weekend" vibe with the dim lighting and close quarters. 

Our server, Dustin, was a wonderful server! He suggested a wine for us, which we absolutely loved. He talked us through the menu, and let us mull over our options. We opted to do the tasting menu. For $60 a person, the table chooses ten dishes - 1 from each section of the menu, but 2 from the robatayaki - to share. While tasting dishes typically leave you hungry, this was the complete opposite. While some dishes were small, others came out in grandiose portions, and by the end of the meal, we were STUFFED. We didn't even finish the last few dishes, although everything was incredible!

TUNA RICE CRACKER - cold // This dish was full of flavor, but the textural contrast is what takes it to the next level. A brick of crispy rice, which is chewy on the inside, is topped with a cool dollop of spicy tuna, with a sweet glaze. The bite ranges from soft to crispy to chewy all at once, and is a textural party in your mouth!

SALMON - specialty sashimi // Thinly sliced pieces of fresh salmon, in a spicy ponzu sauce and topped with soy ginger + scallions. This dish lets the fresh salmon do the talking!

TOFU - crispy // Normally tofu goes unnoticed while on the table, if people even order it at all. But not this tofu! This tofu is fried until it is extremely crispy on the outside, but with a pillowy interior that disintegrates in your mouth. The tofu has two sauces: a pesto and a miso caramel, which both stand out against the mild tofu. Even those who were opposed to ordering tofu helped scarf down this crispy delicacy! 

EDAMAME DUMPLING - small // These little dumps were adorable! The dumplings had a smooth, mild filling made with ground edamame. The flavor was very mellow, yet intriguing. Apparently these are one of the best sellers at Double Knot.

CHICKEN BREAST - robatayaki // Probably the least impressive dish in the meal. The chicken was cooked well, but lacked an explosive flavor compared to the other dishes. 

RIB EYE SCALLION - robatayaki // This was INCREDIBLE, and this is coming from someone who doesn't even like steak. The rib eye was so incredibly tender and juicy, it just melted in the mouth after the first bite. It was topped with a green scallion sauce that was so dynamite, it could have bene paired with cardboard and I'd eat it. Definitely the robatayaki to get!

BEEF SHORT RIB - meat // This was MASSIVE. And so DELICIOUS. The short rib comes to the table whole, and is shredded in front of you. The meat is succulent in the flavorful miso sauce. It's served with lettuce cups and white rice to make lettuce wraps, or you can just jab it with your fork and shovel as much as you possibly can into your mouth.

BROILED SEABASS - fish // By the time this dish came, we were filling up, and I don't think it got the attention it deserved. The seabass was cooked to just past the point of being raw (aka perfect), with glistening insides and a truffle soy glaze on the plate. A simple, understated, perfectly cooked fish. 

CRISPY BRUSSEL SPROUTS - sides // These were good, but not great. The brussels are super crispy, which I loved, and served in a salty fish sauce. While I typically love brussels served like this, I felt the sauce was a bit too pungent or salty, and it made it hard to eat a lot of these.

SPICY TUNA ROLL - sushi // Standard, spicy tuna roll. Fresh fish. 

MOCHI // The tasing menu comes with complimentary mochi. We had two flavors: black sesame and strawberry. These mochi were on the bigger side, with a chewy exterior. The strawberry was a little too sweet for me, but the black sesame tasted like a more mild peanut butter. So delicious and unexpected!!

Double Knot is definitely a spot I will be back to. Will I need to do the tasting menu again? Perhaps, but it was a lot of food. If I were to do it again, I would let the chef choose the menu so I could try some dishes I wouldn't normally. There's tons to chose from the expansive menu, and it's perfect for a weekend dinner or a date night.
name: Double Knot

text:
I'm a fan of this place, minus the long wait. We have had similar ice cream in Thailand and it's really good. Our favorites were the Thai Iced Tea Ice Rolls and Black Sesame Snow Ice. They were delicious and the toppings were great too. Each was about $6.

The thing is, it took a while. I understand that they are going to add more stations or automate it (machine) in the future, but it's tough to make your customers loyal when it takes 20 minutes or more. 

We came this past Sunday after lunch and there wasn't a huge wait. I can't imagine if there is a line out the door. You could wait 45 min for an ice cream.

To be one of the first places in this market space its a huge step. I just wish that they would have put more into the execution because 20 min is way too long.
name: Ice Land
categories: Food, Bubble Tea, Shaved Ice, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts

text:
This is definitely my favorite Thai restaurant in Santa Barbara. I'll be honest- I have really high expectations when it comes to Asian food because 1) I'm Asian!! When I moved to Santa Barbara for college, all I ever craved was Asian food. I tried Pattaya and TAP thai but they were both just okay and never fully satisfied my thai food cravings. THANK GOODNESS that I discovered this place!!! This place serves AUTHENTIC thai food! Everything I've tried here is delicious- pad thai, panang curry, pad see ew and the mongolian beef. My favorite dish here though is the panang curry. They have lunch specials where certain dishes come with an eggroll and soup or salad. 
Also, the ice cream here is AMAZING! I've tried the cookies and thai tea ice cream and the vietnamese coffee mudpie. Their ice cream is made right on the spot (homemade ice cream!!!) They have other unique flavors such as roasted black sesame ice cream and basil mint chip.
Your Choice Resturant is a must-try!!
name: Your Choice

text:
If you're looking for a great place to celebrate a special occasion in philly, this is it. Make a reservation and you'll get seated downstairs. The ambience down there is darker/dim lit with candles and was really romantic.

I would highly recommend the chefs tasting, for 60 a person. I really feel like it's the best deal and the way to get the true experience of the restaurant. 

We did a good mix of seafood and meat dishes and all were delicious. In the chefs tasting you pick one item from each section and two from the robatayaki grill section, for this we did the Kobe beef and shrimp, both were delicious and the Kobe beef was cooked perfectly and was so tender.

Some of our favorites from the tasting menu were the hanger steak, the miso sea bass, and the Kobe beef robatayaki. The one dish I felt could use more flavor was the crab udon. They did serve them in a small bowl for each person which was nice to not share (which would probably be messy). It was still really good but I think more spice/kick to it would have made it better.

The cocktails were great as well, the double knot is smoky flavored though so only get it if that's your thing! Overall wonderful experience finished off the meal with Black sesame Mochi.
name: Double Knot

text: I went to the soft opening of this much anticipated soft serve place, 100% have to try the matcha, black sesame twist on a chocolate cone, with chocolate powder sprinkled on top! The $7 cone price is a little steep, I agree, but with the unlimited toppings it all adds up, so I'm not angry about the price!
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: Amazing soft serve ice cream with unlimited toppings. My favorite is black sesame and matcha! The employees are friendly and service is great. I can't wait to go back and eat more black sesame!
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: I was in Philly for a quick weekend trip and was lucky to find Kuriimii close to where I was staying. It was their soft opening, but their grand opening will be on 9/15-6. Their space is clean and bright. I tried the honeydew soft serve and it was perfect! Good texture, not too sweet. The workers were really nice and helpful even if there was such a large crowd. Since I'm not in Philly often, I'm definitely going to try to make it out when I come. Their matcha black sesame is next on my list!
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: finally, black sesame ice cream in South Philly!! Price is decent and size are a lot too.
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: Simply amazing. Staff welcomed is and were ready to give us samples of every flavor. My greatest advice would be to sample the flavors! When you see something like "charcoal vanilla" or "black sesame" you might be a little shaken. But try them. I'm sure at least 2-3 things in that menu will stand out for sure. Will definitely come back in hopes for a new seasonal flavor.
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: Kuriimii is the only soft serve in the Philadelphia area serving exotic Asian flavors such as matcha, taro, and black sesame. Best of all, they deliver on quality! The space itself is very modern from the beautiful while tiles to ample recess lighting throughout. The flavors are rich yet not too sweet. The combo swirls are definitely reccomended if you're trying to try all if the flavors.. which you will want to do. Best of all, the portions are very sizeable! Definitely big enough to share with your jawn, you know what I'm saying? The unlimited toppings were also a plus. Overall, very pleased with this establishment, won't have to travel up to NY for similar soft serve selections. I will be back!
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
Came here for the soft opening and I already can't wait to come back. Walking into this ice cream shop I immediately felt welcomed by the friendly staff and the bright modern atmosphere. 
For the flavors I tried honeydew, avocado, & matcha. The flavors were so good and creamy, and the chocolate cone was the perfect touch. 
I can't wait to try the other flavors like black sesame & Taro. I highly suggest visiting Kuriimii if you haven't yet.
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
Anyone else feeling that rolled ice cream is rather underwhelming in Chinatown now? 

Which is exactly why Kuriimii is bringing a much needed addition to Chinatown - SOFT SERVE ice cream! ... which is also why I am a big fan, not to mention the Asian inspired flavors to choose from.

Pros:
- Flavors (changes regularly) 
* Black Sesame: nutty, perfect for a black sesame fan but could be stronger in flavor 
* Matcha: no one can agree against green tea, good but typical  
* Black Sesame & Matcha swirl -- perfect balance of the two
*Avocado: rich, creamy, just like an avocado smoothie but in ice cream form. (warning: acquired taste)
- Taro: like taro. 

Tips & Improvements: 
- Because it is soft serve, be mindful of it melting like the polar ice caps. That being said, be smart whether you want a cone or a cup. I had a friend who got a cone, and she would be slurping her ice cream mid-sentence every 5 second. 
- Don't forget about the swirls -- a mixture of two flavors!
- Viet Coffee flavor: unfortunately not creamy and rich like the other flavors, slightly more watery. 
- Interior: clean, modern, but the space is slightly odd like a long tunnel and music can be very loud.
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
This place seems like a bit of a hub for asian-americas on campus, which is cool and a welcoming atmosphere in that sense, so I appreciate what they are trying to do. They have a cool vibe and a TV playing music videos from the 80s/90s for some reason, but hey its cool.

The actual shaved ice, I was less impressed with. I got the taro and it was really flavorless, my friend got the black sesame which was better but def not the best taiwanese shaved ice I've had. The texture of the ice is really well done, but I think they need to add more flavor. Very instragrammable (if that's a word) since it looks very aesthetically pleasing but the taste doesn't match the looks. 

Overall, I may possibly recommend this place if you are in the neighborhood and are just really craving shaved ice, but I probably wouldn't go out of my way to seek it!
name: Winterfell Dessert

text: I am a huge fan of soft serve ice cream and the only time I was ever able to get my hands on some was from the ice cream trucks. With all the hand roll ice cream spots in Chinatown, kuriimii definitely brings a new cold twist to town. Kuriimii specializes in soft serve ice cream with exotic flavors such as: matcha, avocado, black sesame, charcoal vanilla and taro. I can absolutely see myself coming back here many times. One cone is never enough because I'm still debating whether which flavor is my most favorite.
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: Group of 6 of us, we ordered one of everything on the menu. Favorites were: Signature wings, duck salad, Brussels sprouts, mia goreng, chicken sausage fried rice and hands down the fried branzino was the winner! They were out of ribeye and bao. Our favorite of the desserts was definitely banana doughnuts. Tres leches with black sesame was unique, less sweet than everything else. Great service, loud atmosphere. Not good for kids. Would definitely recommend!
name: Sama Sama Kitchen

text: Friendly servers and deliciously creamy soft serve! Would 10/10 recommend to all people who love soft serve or any ice cream-especially for these perfectly unique flavors. My favorites are the taro and black sesame! They give you a good portion and they even make it look picture perfect for those of you wanting to take a photo that makes ur friends wish they were eating with u:) love this new addition to chinatowns list of dessert joints!
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
It's always safe to stick with the classic, creamy (kuriimii), soft serve. Enter, Kuriimii, a soft serve jawn. I stumbled upon their soft opening on the way to Bonchon. Wondering what the long line was about, I walked inside to discover a beautiful ice cream shop with plenty of artwork, seats, and lighting (for the 'gram). 

Avocado and black sesame were recommended to me. Of course, my curious palate went for both. I opted for the chocolate waffle cone with the black sesame and avocado in a cup. Toppings were unlimited and extensive, including fruity pebbles, freshly torched marshmallow, chocolate powder, coconut shavings, etc! Each ice cream was twisted to perfection and the toppings added even more goodness. The flavors were on point and texture was smooth and creamy. Not too sweet, not overly rich - just right. I was told that the up and coming flavor, Ube, will be offered soon. Drool.

I'm not even mad that they're opening after summer (less drippy mess on your hands).
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
Black sesame and condensed milk here are out of this world. Two of the most delicious things I've had and they go so well together. 

The "small" is enough volume to entertain an adult with a sweet tooth for the proper amount of ice-cream eating time, or to split with your friend without either feeling too underwhelmed. Since it's a lovely fluffy type of shaved ice, it's really fun without making you physically feel the guilt one feels after ice cream sometimes. 

I've also heard that their boba is better than average (though I can't attest to this myself)!

It's always full of big groups of people hanging out and playing Jenga. I wouldn't come here for a date over somewhere quieter in the city, but a fun place to spend time with friends.
name: Winterfell Dessert
